results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
$20 to attend. Please be on time and only sign up if you're sure you can be here.


Limited to four attendees. In this workshop, we'll read your work and take more time than in a standard group workshop to go into deeper detail regarding how to strengthen it. From larger structural and character considerations to minor formatting and story bumps, we'll go page by page and suggest how to make your script tighter, evocative, and more compelling. 


Please bring at least four copies of ONE of the following:

1. Ten pages of an original feature screenplay (or a ten or less-page short film) that you wrote yourself.
2. A treatment that you wrote yourself (one to two-page synopsis of the plot) for a proposed original screenplay. Please keep treatments to two pages maximum.


If you haven't written a script or treatment, then come with your questions and a willingness to provide constructive feedback for others.


Regardless of what you bring, be sure to PRINT OUT COPIES so that we can read it together. If you don't print them out, we'll have no way to workshop your work! At least four would be appreciated.

If you haven't written a screenplay or treatment but are curious about the process, then we definitely have a place for you. For beginners, we highly recommend grabbing a copy of The Complete Screenwriter's Manual (http://www.amazon.com/Complete-Screenwriters-Manual-Comprehensive-Reference/dp/0321397932) and screenwriting software (free: CeltX.com, more features: FinalDraft.com)

For more personalized script attention, I offer one-on-one screenplay coverage services. Details and testimonials: http://www.screenplay.guru. 10% off for Cambridge Screenwriting members.

We can't wait to see you!
results.name: Small Group Screenplay Workshop - $20

results.description:
Rita Hunter McGrath of the Columbia Business School has theorized that we are at the end of competitive advantage.  The gold standard for business strategy for many years was “sustainable competitive advantage” - capturing a market or niche through and then extending that advantage.  Companies following this script are going out of business.  Those companies who have thrived through the shifts in human behavior resulting from the digital revolution are using a different script: focus on continuous innovation.

Continuous innovation is a core set of corporate practices that involve strategy leadership and operational iteration; it includes continuous reconfiguration, options valuation, healthy disengagement, but, above all, building an innovation proficiency.

In the frame of digital transformation, the innovation proficiency is what we must envision and practice.  The leading edge of this practice is pairing “cloud native applications” with “continuous delivery of business value,” as pioneered by Amazon and Netflix, and now demonstrated by many others including Allstate, GE, and Lockheed Martin.

Cloud native applications are run in the cloud and on myriad input and output devices, built from scratch with assumptions of mobile and IoT clients.  These also use information and processes from legacy systems (“systems of record”) but do so in a way that protects rather than exposes them; cloud native applications should run against a “digital platform”. 

Continuous delivery of business value is the right-sizing of digital innovation.  Like the lean manufacturing movement in Japan, it shrinks the size of the tools and team to focus on cycle time optimization rather than volume of production.  There are two key dimensions: people and tools.  The people dimension is realized by creating 8-10 person groups that break silos with members of every type of organization on a single team. 

These people and tools come together to build a stack of practices: continuous integration, continuous deployment, and continuous innovation - a system in which collective experience across the team and its customers is rapidly iterated to deliver more business value with each turn of the cycle.

These practices appear to be an empirically demonstrated pattern for successful digital transformation: continuous innovation supported by an enterprise digital platform.
results.name: Continuous Innovation and Digital Platforms- Speaker: Sam Ramji

results.description:
We gather every month for engaging presentations, lively discussions and food/beer! This group gives security researchers in the Greater Boston community the chance to interact with each other more frequently. Each event features three speakers to talk about something a good hacker finds interesting along with discussions about security processes, techniques and much more!

1.  Modernizing Security for the Healthcare Industry  (6:45-7:05)  

by Kevin O'Brien | LinkedIn | Twitter

The Anthem/Blue Cross-Blue Shield data breach in February 2015 created a new sense of urgency around security for healthcare CISOs. Given the highly sensitive information that exists in their environments — including patient data, personally identifiable information, and all manner of intellectual property — there is an increasing interest in understanding the threat surface and finding ways to secure it. From cloud infrastructure to spear phishing, this talk will present a framework for understanding how to understand attack patterns and proactively respond.

About Kevin. CEO and founder of GreatHorn, Kevin O'Brien has been working in the security industry for nearly two decades. He has been an early stage executive at multiple startups, including security pioneers CloudLock, @stake, and Conjur. He has been featured nationally as a guest speaker on NPR's MarketPlace Money (where he provided insight into the Target data breach), written for Tom's Guide about the biometric (in)security of Apple's iPhone 6, and been cited by BuzzFeed on the evolution of the cloud security market, and he is a frequent panelist and moderator within the infosec industry. In addition to his role at GreatHorn, Kevin sits on MassTLC's security advisory board.

2.  Improving the State of Healthcare Information Security as a Security Investigator (7:10-7:30) 

by Roy Wattanasin | Twitter

Last year was rough for data security in the healthcare industry; per the Ponemon Institute, about 43 percent of breaches in 2014 came from the healthcare industry. The FBI has warned that hackers are or will be targeting these organizations, and 2015 already has brought one of the largest healthcare breaches reported to date.

This talk highlights the top healthcare breaches and walks you through them, diving into the role of security investigator (using public information): reviewing how/why each breach happened, when it was discovered, who discovered it, how many people were impacted, and what the organization did to assist them. This talk will also offer recommendations on preventing breaches and engage in a dialogue with the audience. “Time is inevitable, but knowledge and pro-activeness is on your side."

About Roy. Roy Wattanasin is a healthcare information security professional and an adjunct faculty member at Brandeis University. He spends most of his time leading, teaching, and developing information security programs; finding vulnerabilities; performing incident response; and working on many projects. Roy is credited for bringing back Security BSides Boston in 2012, where he was lead organizer for more than three years and now serves as an adviser. Roy enjoys contributing to the community by creating new learning opportunities and conferences. Roy has been an active member of Boston Security Meetup since its early days; he presented the tool of the month and created the @securitymeetup Twitter account.


3.  Operating Docker Securely for Speed and Profit (7:35-7:55)

by Jen Andre | Website | Twitter

What’s old is new again: Docker has made containers the new hotness all over again. It’s been vaunted as another tool to make deployments faster and infrastructure simpler to manage. But with Docker’s popularity has come a lot of debate regarding whether or not Docker containers are safe for production deployments. As with most emerging technologies, this isn’t a question with a clear "yes" or "no" answer; it highly depends on your use case, and how you operationalize the technology.

Out of the box, Docker integrates with Linux technologies natively (process capabilities, user namespaces, AppArmor, SELinux) that "sandbox" the activity a container can do. However, by default it does it in a generic, non-application-specific way. But you can do so much more!

In this talk, Jen will give you an introduction to the Docker security model as it stands today, some possible pitfalls to be aware of, and how to work within that model to make sure you are not introducing risk. She’ll discuss interesting knobs and whistles you can configure (such as AppArmor profiles) to harden your containers, and some interesting open-source tools that make that job easier.

About Jen. In addition to being co-founder at cloud-security company Threat Stack, Jen has worked in R&D at catch-the-bad-guys company Mandiant and as a security analyst and software engineer at Symantec. Jen loves security, open source, and automation, and she especially loves where these things intersect (which is why she likes to talk security at ops-related conferences and blog about these subjects all over the place).

4. Kika Tapas! (8:00-9:00)

Network with security researchers over sangrias and beer!

Sponsored by:

Athena Health

Schedule


6:00 - 6:30: Pizza

6:30 - 6:35: Cybersecurity Opener by Dawn

6:35 - 6:40: Lulzy News by Cindy

6:40 - 6:45: Tool of the month by Will 

6:45 - 7:05:  Modernizing Security for the Healthcare Industry by Kevin O'Brien


7:10 - 7:30:  Improving the State of Healthcare Information Security as a Security Investigator by Roy Wattanasin


7:35 - 7:55:  Operating Docker Securely for Speed and Profit by Jen Andre

8:00 - 9:00:  Kika Tapas

Network with other security enthusiasts!

Physical Security
We'd like to make things easy for Google Security. Everybody should update their meetup profile with their last name and a recent photograph. To do that, click My Profile > View Profile and you'll see the options.

Parking
You may want to allow extra time to find a parking space, but street parking is available on the side streets. Pilgrim Parking, 350 Kendall Street has an $8 rate if you enter after 4pm. Here's a landmark of where to find us at Google: 

Not receiving emails?
Some members have said they're not receiving our emails. You might have unsubscribed to our special announcements. To fix it: Click Settings > Email Updates > Choose Boston Security Meetup under "Updates about your groups" and check off "Announcement about a specific Meetup" and "Announcement to members about the group".

Why are you charging $1? 
It takes an extraordinary amount of effort and time to put on these events. The nominal $1 fee and checkout process serve to verify your attendance and provide a more accurate headcount — and ensure a much better networking experience! Your modest support does enable and encourage us to continue improving these events.

Sales and Recruiters
We appreciate your interest in our events; however, in order to keep the focus on learning and having fun in a casual environment, we request that you not engage in marketing, sales, or recruitment business at our meetups. If you would like to mingle with our members in a professional capacity to promote a product or recruit, please contact us through the Meetup Messenger about sponsorship opportunities.

Looking for speakers! 
If you sent us an abstract of your talk and haven't received a response yet, please send it again. Your message may have been buried in layers of emails. Reminders are helpful!

results.name: Two Views on Healthcare Security, Plus Operating Docker!

Broadmoor Wildlife Sanctuary is a gem. Join us for a photo walk. We will visit some ponds which allows you to follow along the edge of a Marsh for a great view of turtles, fish, muskrats, and great blue herons.

An expansive retreat along Indian Brook and the Charles River, Broadmoor is an ever-changing environment teeming with wildlife: dragonflies darting, turtles basking, otters leaving tracks in the mud or snow, and more than 150 species of birds. Easy-to-rugged well-groomed trails lead you through the shade of mature woodlands into open fields and along the edges of vibrant streams, ponds, and marshland.

We will meet in parking lot.

Photo Walk: 6:00 pm

There is a $5 charge for sanctuary admission. Free for members.

The refuge does not allow dogs.

In the event of bad weather we will reschedule.

Also check the club calendar for other events

The class will be held at the Natick Public Library (Morse Institute Library) and there is ample street parking or a lot across the street. We will be in room 1C which is on the left as you enter (you need to go around the stairs).

Please be respectful of our guest leader and other participants by showing up on time and only RSVPing if you plan on attending.

This should be a lot of fun!

results.description:
A regular mindfulness practice can have huge benefits in your life. Research shows that it can:

Reduce rumination, emotional reactivity, and stress while increasing immune function, focus, relationship satisfaction, empathy, compassion, self-insight and intuition!

During our hour together we'll begin with a relaxing body scan, followed by breathing meditation and metta (aka, loving kindness) practice. 

Metta is a form of mindfulness practice that focuses specifically on building compassion for ourselves and others. It helps give depth to our heart center and be able to do so with discernment. We observe our relationship to ourselves and others in the present moment, accepting it, without judgement. 

Beginners are welcome and encouraged! 

For those who do Reiki, you are welcome to stay for a Reiki share from 7:30-8:30.

results.description:
Calling All New England Marketing Technologists!

We have a date, time and a great list of speakers lined up for our next Boston Marketing Technology Group meeting! Please join us for our next meeting on Thursday, July 9th from 6:30 pm to 8:30 pm as we get together, network, learn and discuss marketing approaches and the technology to support them.

Please sign up for this event on our Meetup page since you won’t be allowed access unless you are on the list! Also, please bring a photo ID.

Speakers

• Doug Banks, Executive Editor, Boston Business Journal

• Jeff Nicholson, VP of Marketing, Kitewheel

• David P. Butler, Founder and CEO, iPositioning Inc.

• John Cass, Author, Digital Marketer, Co-Founder, Agile Marketing Meetup


Agenda

• 6:30: Pizza, refreshments, networking

• 6:50:  Welcome and Announcements

• 6:50 to 8:15: Presentations

• 8:20 Wrap-up


Location:

Microsoft New England R&D Center, 1 Memorial Drive, Cambridge, MA 02142


Directions to Microsoft New England R&D Center

For driving directions as well as to the NERD, please visit: http://microsoftnewengland.com/About


Parking:

Parking is available at 1 Memorial Drive. Details can be found here. http://microsoftnewengland.com/About


THANK YOU to our generous sponsors!

Davis IT and Engineering Davis IT and Engineering is a specialized staffing firm with over 25 years of experience in providing clients and candidates with expert level talent and cutting edge career opportunities. We bring an innovative and collaborative approach to fulfilling staffing needs including contract, contract to hire and direct hire placements. We're proud to have earned Inavero's Best of Staffing Award for providing remarkable service quality to our customers and candidates.

Microsoft New England (MSNE) is a major center for technical innovation and research. Located in the heart of Cambridge, Massachusetts, the MSNE campus includes two buildings—One Memorial Drive and the recently renovated One Cambridge Center. At the core of MSNE is the Microsoft New England Research & Development Center (NERD). NERD is a world-renowned research and software development center, and is home to teams working on critical products and services like Microsoft Office 365 and Microsoft SQL. NERD also serves as a center of gravity for the local tech community, having hosted more than 1,000 events and welcomed more than 100,000 visitors since opening in 2008.

 JLL - A leading New England commercial real estate firm specializing in strategies for owners and occupiers of real estate.

See you there!

- Rick Kollmeyer

Join Emily every Thursday in July for a special vinyasa flow + skincare experience on a beautiful Back Bay roof deck. The goal of the series is to show you that taking care of your body and skin can help you recharge and stay feeling happy, balanced, and energized all summer. Each class will focus on a different skin care product and regimen, paired with a complementing yoga experience.

This series is sponsored by Boston-based Organic Bath Co. and after each class, you'll leave with a sample of their organically made skincare products. Emily will infuse her Ayurvedic knowledge into the flow, explaining why using tools, like facial oils and body scrubs, keep your skin (and tan!) fresh and your mind grounded...the perfect post-practice glow. Come flow and leave feeling beautifully balanced and ready to roll.

results.description:
Dear Boston Culture Lovers,

The ICA free Harborwalk Sounds summer concert series are back again!  With stand-out talent from Boston’s Berklee School of Music set against gorgeous harbor views, the free outdoor concert series is a perfect way to spend a summer evening. Grab a snack from our delicious summer menu and hit the galleries for free to make an entire evening of it.

http://www.icaboston.org/programs/ICA_Summer/

Admission to the museum is also free!

The concert takes place in the rear of the building, the back entrance to the museum.  There are a series of steps and a wide-space area where the musicians set-up their stage.  These steps face the water and have a gorgeous view of the Boston harbor. 


For meeting purposes, lets meet at the bottom (front-row), center  of the steps at 6:30pm. 

Remember, follow the WATER and to go to FRONT ROW, CENTER.  I will try to hold a Meetup sign to help you find the group.

Just a reminder, this is an actual meet-up event, not an advertisement. Please only reserve "YES" if you are definitely attending and intend to meet members of the group. If you reserve "YES", we will be expecting you.  If you reserve "YES" and then have a change of plans, please update the attendance reservation.  A consistent history of not showing up for events may cause you to be removed from the group. 

I look forward in enjoying this event with the group.

Joana

******************************************

Directions and Public Transportation

If you are traveling via public transportation, the nearest T stop is the Waterfront on the Silver Line, http://www.icaboston.org/visit/directions-and-parking/public-transport/

For driving directions, please refer to http://www.icaboston.org/visit/directions-and-parking/

******************************************

Concert Details

Mad Satta

With her cat eyes, crimson lips, hoop earrings, and larger-than-life husky, soulful vocals, Mad Satta frontwoman Joanna Teters calls to mind Amy Winehouse (who the band happens to cover along with the likes of Curtis Mayfield). Since their 2014 debut album Comfort, this 8-piece neo-jazz band has shared the stage with an impressive array of musicians, including Afrika Bambaataa and Casey Benjamin. The ultra-tight self-described “future-soul collective,” band performs their sexy, eclectic R&B with a myriad of instruments including two saxophones, a trumpet, and a flugelhorn, expertly combining the old with the new.

http://www.icaboston.org/programs/performance/music/harborwalk-sounds2015/mad_satta/

results.description:
Are you the type of person who seems to know a little bit of everything especially about the tech scene? Show off your knowledge on the Boston tech market as we host our second annual Tech Trivia Night! Bring a team or come alone and we'll find you some friends when you arrive. Brush up on your tech know-how, knowledge of startups and entrepreneurs in Boston, and of course, Tech in Motion. Trivia not really your game? Join us anyway to network with fellow Boston Techies!

Lauren Landry will be the trivia host for the evening! Lauren is a digital content specialist for Northeastern University, a contributor to Boston magazine and the former associate editor at BostInno, where she wrote nearly 3,500 articles covering all things education and early-stage tech. When she’s not writing, she’s serving as a committee member for Boston Content, mentor for the Emerson Accelerator or teaching content creation and social media at the likes of General Assembly and the Startup Institute.

Tech Trivia Rules and Regulations

No cheating! This means no cell phones and no reference materials.

Don’t shout out the answers.

Five participants are allowed per team.

One answer per team- your team’s answers must be turned in by the end of the countdown.

The answers that have been turned in are final- no corrections!

Each answer is worth one point. There is no penalty for wrong answers.

Rulings made by the Tech in Motion Event Coordinators are final.


Want to learn more about Tech in Motion?

•  Visit TechinMotionEvents.com

• "Like" us on Facebook!

• Join the conversation on Twitter! Share and follow along with @Tech_in_Motion

• Check out our Tech Job Board

• Read insightful content from our speakers across the country on our blog

• Want to sign up for our email list? Click Here!

• Interested in sponsoring a Tech in Motion event? Click Here!

results.description:
Boston Clojure Group Meetups are held at Akamai in the conference rooms on the second floor (200C/D). Please join us for a night of Clojure related discussion and group activities.

Meet & Greet starts at 6:00. Group activities will begin at 6:30.

Agenda for this meeting:

Title: Hands-on Datomic Experience

Presenter: Jochen Rau


Abstract & Agenda:
Datomic is a non-relational database with a unique set of powerful features, like immutability, the notion of time, or its flexible schema.

In this workshop, we are going to take a deep dive into Datomic's data model and it's query language Datalog. After a gentle start with a simple schema and some basic queries, we will explore some more sophisticated concepts like rules, aggregates, expressions, and pulling.

At the end of the workshop, we will take a step back an look at the architecture, deployment options and Datomic's place in Clojure's ecosystem.

Please bring your laptop with Leiningen and your favorite Clojure editor installed if you want to follow the examples hands-on.

Bio:
Jochen works as full-time Clojure/Java developer at Infinite Cloud - a small consulting company based in the Pioneer Valley. He is primarily working on high volume/velocity data analytics and Semantic Web applications. To get the issue tracker out of his head, he goes camping with his five daughters or tortures his drum set.

results.name: Hands-on Datomic Experience

The 50 cent charge is totally voluntary and is only to approximately cover the meetup charge, however It is suggested that you buy a drink or something else there, to compensate the hosting establishment.

New people are very welcome and will probably will play their first few hands, about an hour of instruction, with the Meetup organizer and selected players before playing at-large with the rest of the group.

This is SOCIAL CARDS conversation is encouraged, however please be aware of when it is your turn to bid or play a card, we try to keep the fun balanced and considerate of everyone between the two activities.


https://maps.google.com/maps?hl=en&tab=wl&outputclassic&dg=brw

1. Route 107 AKA Highland Ave toward Jackson St

<a>2. Turn right onto Jackson St 0.3 mi</a>

3. Turn right onto Jefferson Ave <a>0.1 mi 44 Jefferson Ave Salem, MA 01970</a>

 PUBLIC:

Buses stop at Washington and Derby

Bus numbers 450, 451, 455, 456, 459, 465

From there walk past the Post Office then past Salem House of Pizza on Margin, then past bend in road at Salem Police Station on Margin.

Now going straight ahead you will be on Jefferson, (because Margin St diverts to the right), then past U-Haul at minor bend in road.  

Vinny's is opposite Salem Fibers on Jefferson, about 1/2 mile total.

Vinney's can not be seen from bus stop due to the offset and bends in the roads. But, you should be able to see the Salem House of Pizza, tucked into the corner (of this not very Square?) past the Post Office.

The Salem Train Station is further away, about 3/4 mile, at Washington and Bridge Streets.

Additionally:

Both: The 450 and 456 Buses have stops at ("route 107 AKA Highland Ave" at the Essex, Dalton, Broad, and  Jackson intersection), Just past the Collins Middle School on the hill. You can walk down Jackson street, by the side of the Collins Middle School to Jefferson street, Vinney's will be to the right.  This walk is slightly shorter than the walk from the Washington Street stop about 3/8 mile.

Featuring:

Zareh Artinian, Author

Dave Riese, Author 

Thursday, July 9th  6:45 - 8:45 PM

Join us for a night of fiction and fun at the beautiful Northeastern Alumni Center with writer Zareh Artinian.  He will read from Paper Daisies, a screenplay for a feature length film that he adapted from a Young Adult novel he wrote and self-published for the Amazon Kindle. It's set in Brooklyn, NY, in the 1980s.

Dave Riese will introduce his novel, Echo from Mount Royal, which he independently published locally in January 2015. The novel takes place in the Montreal of 1951 and concerns the unusual courtship of an 18-year-old girl. After a short reading, he will discuss his experience publishing his novel and some of the challenges he faces marketing the book.

Please reserve by July 8 at 7 pm.  Thank you.

Look forward to seeing at least thirty of you -:)

Inactive members are highly encouraged to attend this meeting.  There is currently a waiting list of 14 artists who want to join our group.  So I appreciate hearing from all of you.  Thank you for your understanding.

Members pay $10 as on Monday night, non-member drop-in is $25.  Membership fee for each month of $25 brings discounts on drawing and painting sessions and classes.  Pay membership fee online (see left-hand column) via paypal or credit card, or in person with cash or check.  First session of the month would therefore be $35 ($25 membership fee plus $10 session fee) and each session thereafter would be $10.

results.description:
A night of boundary dissolution, where we find all antennas both transmit and receive. Band, audience, ambiance, sound check, performance?? We dance in joy that is experiencing the absurdity of these distinctions.

Sonic Osmosis is our attempt to leak through the walls that box in free improv music and art.

Take a bunch of musicians and artists, some of whom have never met, herd them into one space and allow them to freely interact -- no set times, no sound check, no stage, and no guarantee that an audience member won’t grab your bongos and start beating on them!

Leave your expectations at the door, and pay attention! Someone might be talking to you from the other side of the room. Wander through the space to hear different mixes of what's happening, and if you feel inspired, jump into the fray! Do a dance! Recite a poem! Make some noise! Or just chill on the couch...no one will shine an unwanted spotlight on you.

Sonic Osmosis is a monthly series at Out of the Blue Too Gallery (541 Mass. Ave., Cambridge, MA).

Admission to our events is a $3-10 sliding scale for “audience members” (those who do not declare their art tools at the door), but we also ask the “artists” to donate to the gallery as well, cuz we all in this together! All money goes to the gallery, because this place rocks and we want to keep it around for a long, long time.

If you’d like to attend or participate, please join us!
results.name: Sonic Osmosis #2 - Improv Free-For-All

results.description:
BSFW is going to its fourth Readercon. If you are new to writing or an old hand ready to be published, Readercon is for you. Amazing and well known authors, agents, publishers, and editors all come together to share what they know, hang out with friends, and drink heavily. 

From the Readercon website:  

"Readercon is an annual conference or convention devoted to "imaginative literature" — literary science fiction, fantasy, horror, and the unclassifiable works often called "slipstream."

A typical Readercon features over 150 writers, editors, publishers, and critics, attracting prominent figures from across the U.S., and from Canada, the U.K., and occasionally even Australia and Japan. They are joined by some 600 of their most passionate and articulate readers for a long weekend of intense conversation.

Readercon is the only convention ever to be honored by a World Fantasy Award nomination (Special Award, Non-Professional, 2010) for its organizers."

If you want to go with us then please, RSVP and go here, to get on the contact list, and send me a message because I am not using Meetup to coordinate this trip.  It's already one of the least expensive cons you'll ever go to, but if you go as a group, the trip is even more fun and cost effective as possible.  Go to the Readercon website and register soon!  

-Spidercam
results.name: BSFW Goes to READERCON 2015

The Inner Engineering online program includes guided meditations, powerful breathing techniques, and deeply engaging discourses about the nature of the mind and practical wisdom to manage life’s situations.

Inner Engineering is a combination of methods derived from the ancient science of yoga that addresses every aspect of human well-being — from your body, mind and emotions to the essential life energy within.

This 1 hour introduction to Inner Engineering explains the fundamental approach of the program in a live setting that offers you the opportunity to ask a trained Isha teacher questions about the program and practices available.

results.description:
Boston CanvasCon is the first event of its kind to bring together Canvas-enthusiasts and newcomers who teach with Canvas. We're here to find common ground, to support each other in improving educational outcomes, and to learn to better use technology to engage our students, whether adult, traditional or K-12. Tracks for faculty bring you back to why you love teaching in the first place. We help you integrate technology better in the classroom, in ways that make sense for you and your students. Learn hands-on Canvas skills to make you a Canvas master. Gain confidence if your school has just moved to Canvas. Tracks will focus on learning the tools, teaching effectiveness, design thinking, and the coolest tech.
Sessions
More Sessions to Be Announced

Universal Design in Canvas: Tools That Work
Beth Ritter-Guth, Director of Instructional Design and Director of American Honors, Union County College

Universal Design allows course materials to be fine tuned to individualized learning styles. UD provides accessible ways for students to receive content, manipulate content, and submit content. This interactive presentation will provide attendees with several tools that can be used to foster universal design within Canvas.

Canvas and the Case Method: Canvas at HBS
Paul Craig, Associate Director, Learning Technology Services, Educational Technology Services, HBS IT
Andy Hyde, Instructional Designer, Educational Technology Services, HBS IT
Jeanne Po, Director, Learning Technologies and Instructional Design Services, Educational Technology Services, HBS IT

During this session, presenters will discuss how Harvard Business School is utilizing Canvas to support case-based teaching and learning, promote collaboration in new and meaningful ways, and share best practices and lessons learned and over the course of the Canvas pilot at HBS. Presenters will illustrate how the lessons learned in the pilot will be applied during the Canvas roll out at HBS.

Can We Use Canvas for This?
Molly Bonnard, Courseware Services Manager, University of Pennsylvania

Once faculty and staff become comfortable using Canvas in their courses, interest will grow in using the LMS for other purposes since it is a tool "everyone knows." Learn about the University of Pennsylvania's experience developing policies and providing support for non-course use of Canvas like placement exams, freshman orientation, and alumni groups.

Teaching Mega-Courses with Canvas
Larry Bouthillier, Instructor in Computer Science, Harvard Extension School. A programming course with over 200 students? Must be Coursera or codeacamy? No. It’s Canvas at Harvard. The course contains 100+ pages of designed content with a custom navigation scheme, several dozen assignments, Canvas-managed peer-review of student code by other students, weekly reflection surveys, 75+ instructional videos, and the use of external tools for managing class. See what you can learn for your own larger courses. Chiropractic Course Design: Making Sure Your Course is in Alignment
Jean Marrapodi, Ph.D, Citizen's Bank and formerly, The New England College of Business

Participants in this session will explore course mapping: aligning objectives, content, and assessments to ensure that the main purpose of an eLearning course remains the main purpose, and that we measure the appropriate outcomes. For faculty, you'll learn how to narrow down your subject and ensure you meet your goals and the learners succeed in class. "You're Speakin' My Language"
Kate Hill, Director of Online Learning, Cincinnati Christian University In all educational arenas, we have one common goal: to educate students. However, many times Instructional Designers and Faculty don't speak the same language. Without experience on both sides of these positions, it is often difficult to understand and empathize with the unique issues that must be faced. So, how do we get Instructional Designers and Faculty on the same Canvas Front Page??
results.name: Boston CanvasCon

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball.

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.
results.name: Friday Lunchtime Soccer (OUTDOOR)

results.description:
This walk is on a paved path through the woods. This path is stroller friendly or you could carry your child. It is a little hilly, but appropriate for most fitness levels. We alternate walks between the inner and outer loops which are both under 3 miles. It usually takes less than an hour. We walk past a playground too, so we could stop and play there for a while. Afterwards, we sit at the picnic tables under the trees by the visitor center and feed our babies, chat, etc. 

We will meet outside the visitor center in the upper parking lot on the Saugus side of the park, past the Kasabuski Skating Rink.  There are bathrooms with a changing table in the visitor center too.

Running late?  No prob. You can always meet up with us at the picnic tables next to the visitor center after we finish the walk. 

***By popular demand this is set as weekly event.  If the weather is bad we can change it to a different day or skip the week.

results.description:
Cohosted with Boston Walking Meetup Group and LL Bean. Clinic is held on shore.

Fly fishing is an angling method in which an artificial "fly" is used to catch fish. The fly is casted using a fly rod, reel, and specialized weighted line. Casting a nearly weightless fly or "lure" requires casting techniques significantly different from other forms of casting.

LL Bean's expert fly-caster, Brian will take us through every step in this hour-long hands-on clinic near the Charles River. Brian will show us the 4-part cast, the roll cast and teach us about proper line techniques. (LL Bean is also hosting a stand-up paddleboarding clinic for $25 at this time, so there will be lots of activity.)

After the lesson, we can get something to eat or drink in nearby downtown Dedham.

results.description:
For New Members AND NON-Members:

For every sailor who walks through our door, start here! This FREE Orientation class will get you familiar with how everything works at CBI. The orientation class is the gateway to everything that CBI has to offer, whether you’re a seasoned sailor or brand new to boats. Done entirely on the dock, your orientation will include a guided tour of CBI’s boats and facilities, an overview of our classes and programs, as well as plenty of time to ask the questions that matter to you as a sailor. All orientations meet at the base of the American Flag Pole out on the dock, and runs for about half an hour. All are welcome to this class!


Afterwards, we invite you to meet one another and ask about other Orientation class attendees' prior experience with sailing. Perhaps you can find a friend to take the Beginner Sailing classes together with once you join. 

Friday Nights are also when CBI members go out for Informal Racing, so it is an exciting night to watch the sailors and learn more about how you can progress your skills after learning to sail. Certainly ask your Orientation instructor about the Friday Night Informal Racing and Informal Instruction if he or she does not mention it. If you have any questions, please feel free to post below!

results.description:
Open year round, dawn to dusk. Revere Beach, the oldest public beach in America, celebrated its 100th anniversary in 1996. Revere Beach faces Massachusetts Bay, five miles north of Boston. Its hard sand shore forms a great crescent along the blue ocean for miles, sloping away gradually out to sea, creating an ideal bathing beach. With the Nahant and Winthrop peninsulas framing the horizon, the distant lighthouses and the steamers passing far out to sea, the scenic panorama viewed from the beach by day or night is unsurpassed.

A long flat sidewalk runs alongside the length of the beach, with covered seating areas available, a bathhouse, and a bandstand for summer concerts. Also along Revere Beach Boulevard are restaurants, ice cream shops, and, of course, Kelly's Roast Beef - a Revere Beach favorite.

We will meet at 5:45 and start our walk at 5:50, so if you are running late, please catch up!


Directions: 
Revere Beach is on Revere Beach Boulevard, which is off Route 1A. From Route 128, you would take Rt 1, then Rt 60, then eventually Rt 1A to Revere Beach Boulevard. There is on-street parking the length of the beach, as well as streets parallel to Revere Beach Boulevard. There is also a large parking lot about halfway down the beach.

Meet at: 
At the bandstand, which is at the south end of the beach (heading toward Boston).

If you need to reach me to locate us: 
Call me on my cell:[masked]-4624.
results.name: Fri 07/10 at 5:45PM - Revere Beach in Revere

results.description:
This is a time for getting away from the city and building our community with reflection, discussion, music, food, and a physical task. Paul and Pat will be opening up their home in Vermont again.

The menu is vegan. The cost for the weekend will be $50 per person. This pays for food and transportation/gas. Please do let the organizers know if you would need support with this, because we do have subsidized spots available.
We also need to know who is willing to drive (you will be reimbursed for gas).

The location says CCI, but we in actuality will meet at CCI on Friday evening at 6 pm and head up to Vermont for the weekend. We will be back on Sunday evening around 5 pm.

There are a range of sleeping accommodations, including shared spaces and the option of camping out.  When you RSVP, please indicate if you would like to camp out and if you have any particular needs or desires. 


If you are able, be prepared to stack logs.

Let us know if you have any specific questions about accessibility or anything else! We will be in touch with more details and  a rough schedule as soon as we can.

To arrange for payment, please contact Duney.  We can accept payments at the retreat, but we want to know in advance how you plan to pay (or if you need a subsidized spot).

SEATING IS LIMITED - FREE REGISTRATION REQUIRED

Gary

A message from The Wine Bottega:

Join us for our weekly Friday night tasting. It's always something delicious, educational and interesting. You can sign up for our weekly e-mail to get the details! (See the bottom of the homepage)

A NOTE FROM THE ORGANIZER:

Okay... We all love free stuff. That's why we're members of this group! So I'm going to post this as a recurring weekly event, as long as people are enjoying it. Gary

Experience lying in a crystal grid which centers on opening your crown, brow, and root chakras to help you connect with your Spirit Animal Totem. This grid will encourage your connection to your personal Animal Spirit Guide and support communication and messages. Being aware of your personal Animal Totem may allow you to feel their presence and guidance in your everyday life.  Totems can also assist healers while offering healing to others.  Grids will be enhanced with guided meditation, drumming, Tibetan bowl, aromatherapy and journaling. Discount offered to purchase crystals. Instructor Trish Matthies[masked]  or [masked]

Friday,  July 10  at 7:00-9:00pm…$44  cash or check

Please mail or drop off payment to hold your spot in class. if payment is not reached within 7 days of you signing up for class your space in class is not guaranteed.

Mail to:

The Healing Moon

34 School St, Suite 101

Foxboro, Ma 02035


What is a crystal grid?  A specifically chosen set of crystals are used together to create a desired energy shift or healing. The crystals do not work independently, but are charged to react and work together. Although the crystals in the grid rest are placed the ground flat, the energy of the grids are 3- dimensional to completely surround you. Attendees lay comfortably on mats with pillows and blankets with the crystals around them on the floor as well as some placed on chakras.

results.description:
What is Skate Boston? For all the details, click on this link:

Skate Boston official site 


Get all the details here: What is Skate Boston?

"Skate Boston" is an annual weekend inline skating event organized by the Inline Club of Boston. Enjoy multiple skate routes through our historic city, escorted by members of National Skate Patrol. There will be group lunches and dinners, providing an opportunity for skaters to socialize. Skaters of intermediate, advanced, and expert levels are encouraged to participate! Due to the challenges of urban skating, this event is not designed for beginners. However, novice skaters are invited to participate in separate instructional workshops and beginner social skates hosted by the Inline Club of Boston throughout the year. This weekend attracts many skaters from Boston, other U.S. cities, Canada, and around the world!

What level of skating ability is required to participate in this event?

Skate Boston is designed for intermediate to advanced level skaters. We will be skating in city streets, so you must be comfortable skating in a large group with traffic. Participants must be able to control speed (including on hills), have strong stopping and turning skills, and be comfortable with varied terrain (rough pavement/ pot holes/jumping on and off curbs, etc.) Please see the list of recommended skating skills for "Sunday Morning City Skate" on the ICB website.

results.description:
Talented Psychic Medium Yulia Applewood presenting:

PSYCHIC DEVELOPMENT CLASS
Friday, June 5th, 2015 from 7:00pm to 9:00pm .... CALL TO SIGNUP[masked]
In this class students will learn the basics of psychism and mediumship in a safe and supportive environment. Students will discover their own innate psychic skill and talents through a series of exercises designed to gently open the third eye and make them aware of the unseen world around them. This class will focus on psychic protection and spiritual hygiene and spiritual awareness and will be instrumental in identifying and developing the individual psychic skills of each student. We will also explore the wonders of mediumship and connect with the realm of spirit through a small group séance. In each class students will have the opportunity to experiment with different psychic tools and techniques along with learning a brief history about each practice. In the first class we will discuss Tarot cards and learn the systems behind the symbolism in the cards, which make them such a useful tool in divination. We will also experiment with dowsing, using both rods and pendulums to answer simple questions and find lost items, we will introduce as well the ancient art of scrying on liquid, flame and crystal surfaces. We will also delve into palmistry and learn how to be prepared for certain changes in our own lives by studying some of the major lines on our hands. We will learn how to read tea leaves and throw bones as well. Both of these famous systems from antiquity have complex histories and variations that will also be discussed. Cost: $25.00

results.description:
Friday nights are generally for more experienced students, as we work through some different parts of Fiore's works in a more open format.  New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (c[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.

What is Boston Bike Party? It's a monthly, social bike ride around the city with music, lights, and fun. It's a great way to connect with the awesome bike community and make some new friends. This 1 minute video will explain what its like to be a part of Boston Bike Party.

We have over 400 cyclists coming via our Facebook Event Page.  Check it out and to see who else is going and to easily invite your friends.

results.description:
Use the power of conscious, connected breathing to still the mind, clear emotions, and deeply relax & connect with yourself. Learn a proven and effective practice to gain freedom from the ‘monkey mind’, attain joy and clarify your intention. Take the opportunity to clear away what's been stressing you out. Find relief from pain, & understand why behaviors & situations are showing up in your life! Please wear comfortable clothing & do not eat heavily for a few hours prior to class. $35 or class card x 2 + $5
Lisa Jones has been an internationally accredited breathing therapist practitioner since 1998,who has taught thousands of individuals and supported their journeys into the body/mind realm through her workshops and private sessions. She is committed to building breathing in sacred circle communities and adding to the ones currently established in NH, MA and RI. Her belief is that when we breath consciously as a community the amount of healing that takes place is phenomenally amplified for individuals, their loved ones and the planet. Lisa invites you to share the insights and joy that come from incorporating body, mind, and spirit into your wellness
results.name: BREATHING INTO LIFE: A Sacred Circle with Lisa Jones

Here's the game plan:

8:00 - Toss the disc around, meet folks, be merry

8:10 - Overview of the rules, safety, etc - then divide into teams

8:20 - Play!!!!!!

10:00 - Conclude the meetup and begin socializing.

Here's what we humbly ask of you (works great as a checklist):

Dress for the weather

Bring a white and a dark-colored t-shirt. Grey is evil. If you wear grey you may be asked to wear a light or dark "pinnie of shame."

Arrive on time to be guaranteed a spot in a game

RSVP is recommended so you can be notified if the game is canceled

Bring WATER!

If you are a regular, please consider bringing a buck for the Frisbee Fund

As usual, we will supply the frisbees, cones, first aid supplies (hopefully will never be used) and our pretty smiles. As we periodically mention, all these supplies are paid out-of-pocket by your loving Frisbee organizers and everyone has been so generous with their donations to-date. Thank you and let's keep the dream alive!

Havana Night Salsa is Boston's biggest salsa dance party featuring salsa dancing and lessons with Salsa y Control, an amazing venue filled with 300+ welcoming salsa dancers, an inexpensive parking garage next door, and public transport on Mass Ave. (Red Line, Buses 1, 64 etc.) one block away! 

288 Green St, Central Sq, Cambridge

Have your party with Havana Club! Birthday? Graduation? Wedding? Outing w/ co-workers? This is the best place to celebrate. 


Driving Directions: Take Storrow or Memorial Drive to River St. (where the two gas stations are), then a right on Mass Ave, a right on Pearl St (where FootLocker and Putnam Furniture is), and your first right on Green St. 

Parking: There is a large, inexpensive ($1.50/hr, $6/night maximum) parking garage right next door - you can't miss it!

Walking Directions (from Red Line's Central Stop): From Mass Ave take a left on Prospect St then a left on Green St. It is a one minute walk. 

Please note that the Friday Night Salsa parties are 21+.

21+. $12 (Admission includes lesson and party)

Dress Code: Smart Casual to Elegant

(No ball caps, no work boots, etc.)
Beer, Wine, Mixed Drinks, etc. available at Bar
No partner required
Beginners very welcome
No need to pre-register
Music format: 65% salsa, 25% bachata,
10% merengue/cha-cha-cha

I  <3 the midnight dance performances! You do not want to miss those.

Havana Club Salsa is Boston's biggest salsa dance party featuring salsa dancing and lessons with Salsa y Control, an amazing venue filled with 300+ welcoming salsa dancers, an inexpensive parking garage next door, and public transport on Mass Ave. (Red Line, Buses 1, 64 etc.) one block away! 288 Green St, Central Sq, Cambridge. I pay $6 and I am good for the night. ($1.50/hr, $6/night maximum)

Have your party with Havana Club! Birthday? Graduation? Wedding? Outing w/ co-workers? This is the best place to celebrate.

Driving Directions: Take Storrow or Memorial Drive to River St. (where the two gas stations are), then a right on Mass Ave, a right on Pearl St (where FootLocker and Putnam Furniture is), and your first right on Green St. Parking: There is a large, inexpensive ($1.50/hr, $6/night maximum) parking garage right next door - you can't miss it!

Walking Directions (from Red Line's Central Stop): From Mass Ave take a left on Prospect St then a left on Green St. It is a one minute walk. Please note that the Friday Night Salsa parties are 21+.

results.description:
Organizer: Joe Ciarcia -[masked]
ONLY RSVP IF YOU ARE ATTENDING. You do not need to RSVP if you are not attending.


=========================

Read the entire description before you RSVP and answer all of the questions that are part of the RSVP process. Failure to answer them will result in your removal from this event.

If you underestimate the demands of this event; overestimate your experience, knowledge, skills or abilities; or come unprepared you put yourself or others at risk so consider this before you decide to participate.

=========================

***** NEW SIGNUP PROCEDURE *****
If you are interested in participating in this event sign up for the waiting list. I will add people that (1) answer all of the questions that are part of the RSVP process and (2) have done similar hikes within the past three months.


What We're Doing...

Glen Boulder is one of my favorite trails in the Whites and taking Glen Boulder via Boot Spur is my favorite way to get to Mt. Washington so... that's what we're going to do. One of the things that makes the Glen Boulder Trail so wonderful is that it has one of the lowest tree lines in the Whites. The first leg of this hike will take us up to Mt. Washington @ 6,288 feet via Glen Boulder and Boot Spur gaining 4,678 feet of vertical in the process. The views are absolutely fantastic and while the car spotting is a little inconvenient, this part of the hike alone will make it 100% worth it! From the summit of Mt. Washington we will head southwest on the Crawford Path darting off occasionally to pick up a summit here and there. In addition to Mt. Washington we will also summit Mt. Monroe at 5,372 feet, Mount Eisenhower at 4,760 feet, and Mount Pierce at 4,312 feet. If the group is feeling REALLY great we may add Jackson to the list, but no promises.


Use this link for more information about the summits and trails:

• http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/1-Mt-Washington-6288

</a>

<a href="http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/1-Mt-Washington-6288">• http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/4-Mt-Monroe-5384

• http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/11-Mt-Eisenhower-4780--27-Mt-Pierce-4310


Guests are not permitted.


Dogs are permitted - Just like humans, dogs need to be in good shape to do this hike. Be sure to bring a leash in case you need to use it and a copy of their current rabies vaccination.

Trip Summary...

Distance: 14.4 miles
Vertical rise: 5,993 feet
Book Time: 10 hours and 12 minutes


This event is considered to be ADVANCED because of the pace, distance, and elevation gain. We could alter our plans because of fatigue, weather, and/or other conditions - there is no guarantee we will complete the entire event as described here.

We start as a group, hike as a group, and finish as a group. Our pace will be that of the slowest hiker. This trip isn't for you if you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us, if you want to head off on your own, or if you are slower than the group and expect us to constantly wait for you.

You need to become self-reliant by learning about the route and potential hazards since you are ultimately responsible for your own safety.

What to Bring...


Headlamps are required
Don't forget sunscreen, glasses/eye protection from the wind, layers, snacks etc.
Bring CASH, the visitor's center does not accept credit cards.


Use this link for a list of items needed for a three season day hike* (*exception, NO COTTON EVER!!!):

• http://files.meetup.com/492954/Three_Season_Dayhike_gear_list.pdf

Do not rely on others to have extra items to share with you at the meeting spot or on the trail. You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip. 

Weather...

Dangerous weather conditions will cancel this event - I will post an update and/or send an email to all confirmed participants.

Use this link for the current weather forecast:

• http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lat=44.2702759660005&lon=-71.30332832999966

• http://www.mountwashington.org/weather/summit_forecast.php

• http://www.mountwashington.org/weather/mesonet/

Directions...


We will meet at the Crawford Connector Trailhead off of 302 (just  to spot cars and then head on over to the Glen Boulder Trailhead which is just south of Wildcat Ski Area on Rt. 16. According to Google Maps, the distance from Boston is 160 miles and the drive time is 2 hours, 36 minutes.


Use this link for customizable driving directions:

• https://www.google.com/maps/preview?f=d&daddr=44.223880,-71.411305%28Crawford+Connector+Trailhead%29

Carpools


While carpooling is encouraged you are responsible for coordinating your own rides. Use the comments section below to communicate with others who may also be looking to share a ride. If you do share a ride be sure to share the expenses (gas and tolls).

Random Group of Hikers Disclaimer...

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hike Safe Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.

results.description:
SPECIAL NOTE: This Saturday we have a special event for the runners training for the full marathon. We will meet at Davis Square earlier in the morning (7:15AM). Some TAA volunteers will drive all the full marathoner runners to Bedford, to the other end of Minuteman trail. Runners will run all the way back to Davis Square (11 miles in total)!

Please note that this is a special meetup just for the runners targeting full marathon. Please find the other meetup event on the same day if you are targeting half marathon. 

Group run logistics: Please come prepared for a short run (or run/walk). Leave your bags, etc. at home or in your car so that you can run easily. Please make sure to arrive 10 minutes early to look for parking, find the location, etc. 
Coach will brief you at the beginning of the run about the distance and direct you through stretching exercises. It is absolutely OK to run/walk in the beginning. Many of us are first-time runners. So please don’t be shy :-).

Registration fees:  If you have not yet registered and paid the fees, please do so at this page.  http://www.teamaidasha.org/register Please contact us at [masked] if you have any questions. 

Program details:  TeamAIDAsha is a beginner-friendly marathon/half-marathon training and fund-raising program. We train runners for their full or half marathon races and runners raise donations for AID and Asha. Both beginner and experienced runners are welcome. Anyone is welcome to RSVP and join us for the group runs up to four time with no obligations. We request formal registrations after attending four group runs.

If you missed the information session you can get an overview of this training and fund-raising program from here.

Looking for more runners: We are always looking for more runners. If any of your friends, family members or colleagues to give us a try and join this meetup group.


Waiver: Lawyers make us do this :-).  By running with TeamAIDAsha program you are agreeing to our official waiver at: http://www.teamaidasha.org/waiver.html


About AID-Boston

Association for India's Development (AID) is a non-profit, volunteer movement committed to promoting sustainable, equitable and just development, especially at India’s grassroots. We meet once a week at MIT. Anyone is welcome to attend. Visit AID-Boston at: www.aidboston.org

About Asha-MIT

Asha tries to catalyze socio-economic change in India through education of underprivileged children. We meet once a month at MIT. Anyone is welcome to attend. Visit Asha Boston/MIT at: http://www.ashanet.org/mit/

results.description:
We'll start with a 10 minute warm up section that will include light cardiovascular moves, foam roller work and dynamic stretching. This will help to prepare the body for the torture...I mean, workout, ahead.

Next will be the main workout consisting of  mainly bodyweight exercises(squats, lunges chin-ups, TRX rows inverted rows incorporating some cardiovascular sequences such as jump rope, burpees, jumping jacks and maybe some boxing. Of course we'll end with some focused core work which could include bicycles,dolphin planks rollouts and bridge work. All of it customized according to your level of course! Hopefully we'll be able to incorporate some team games when we have a larger group.

It all starts at 8! Call me at[masked] if you have any questions or concerns.

results.description:
This is the reoccurring meetup for the weekly open water swims at Walden Pond. A well attended venue for triathletes training for races of all distances.

The gate opens at 7 a.m. and the Parking is right off of Walden St. Walden charges to park a their lot ($5) via a computerized parking attendant that takes cards. I'd recommend the annual pass if you think you're going to come to more meetups. Alternatively, It's a short distance from Concord High School. Some people avoid the parking fee by parking near Concord High School and then walk/ride their bike over to Walden. Click here for the map of the parking.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Across and back from the beach (Pictured above) is a little over a mile mile; a perfect distance for those training for 70.3 and Ironman races.

There are also some close to shore routes for people getting better acquainted with open water (see distance maps). We meet near the lifeguard house right on the beach closes to Walden street. Here is the map of walden pond.

This meetup is important because you always want to swim in groups if you can. Make certain that you look out for each other. Don't attempt to swim across the pond if you haven't trained for that distance. Always match up with someone or a group that swims your pace. The beauty of Walden is that you can swim very close to shallow water and get some good open water training in.

If there are people that are looking to go long for the first time, let me know in advance and I may be able to swim angel, or get a swim angel group together. That way we can do it in a controlled and safe environment.

For those that are really new and nervous about open water swimming, stay tuned for a beginners clinic that I'll put on in the summer.
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be by the Lifeguard house

This week's ride is a Ipswich to Boxford Loop . It is an up and back down ride. The first 17 miles nets a gain of 189 ft. On the return you get to go back down to sea level for a total of 35 miles. There is an optional loop at either the end or the beginning to Jeffery's Neck which extends to the total distance to 43 miles. We'll start from the Ipswich MBTA station. The ride can be viewed at the link below. This is a ramble. We will try to maintain an average moving speed of 13 - 15 mph. Of course the return may pick up speed and turn more into a romp 15+ mph. But there will be no one left behind.

Route: http://www.mapmyride.com/routes/view/758174887

Remember to read the group 'pages' for more information: Helmets are required on all rides, and you assume full responsibility for coming with a bicycle in good working order (e.g., no brake problems, etc.). You also assume full responsibility for your own safety on these trips.

results.description:
Hello everyone!  Here are some upcoming dates that we can have access to the First United Baptist Church at 99 Church street in Lowell for our meetup group.

This is a great place to meet with ample parking right beside the Church; a retail area parking lot.

I will have Mitsy Kit packages for people to look at and purchase if so desired, to make pillows, lap size quilts, baby blankets, or to pick out supplies for a more custom project like totes, wall hangings or cross over bags.  We can also use this time to learn how to use the kits and get started on your project!

For those who would like to help make the quilting kit products for the blind, I will have my sewing machine and welcome anyone else bringing their portable sewing machine if you would like.  Please just let me know in advance so that I know how many tables we will need.

Please RSVP so that I know who to expect.  I look forward to meeting you!

results.description:
We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (circa[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.

New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

See you there!

If there's no parking in Thorndike lot, look for parking on the side streets.
results.how_to_find_us: Look for us in the triangle between Magnolia and Thorndike Fields, just off the bike path.
results.name: (Arlington) - Intermediate Swordplay, Dagger and Grappling

group.name: Boston Armizare -- Historical Swordplay and More!

results.description:
Lets all go to the Giust Gallery, in Woburn MA!

This is a great chance to get to know a real gem here in the Boston area!
It's a living museum/art studio all in one!

IT IS A FREE EVENT TO ATTEND.

They are a historic business whose roots reach back to Boston in the 1800's! Started by Pietro Caproni and his brother Emilio, they traveled around Europe making plaster molds of classical priceless sculpture, producing reproductions of the sculptures for schools and museums as well as the Boston Symphony Hall!

The Giust Gallery is now owned and operated by a great sculptor in Woburn MA, They were recently hired to restore the Lion and Unicorn that is located at the old State House, remember the time capsule???!!

This meet-up will be a visit to offer some information but also if you want to purchase a plaster cast.... They also sell sculpture supplies and materials for those who sculpt!

YOU NEED A CAR TO GET THERE.
I'm sure there is public transportation, but lets all aim for efficiency:) Suggestion: carpool a group to save time.

We will need to organize transportation issues all in advance, so post a comment that you need help getting there, and back. I'm very excited to offer this event, I hope you all take a look and sign up!
results.name: Visit the Giust Gallery. A historic arts business here in the Boston area!

results.description:
Run Details: Meet up with The Most Informal Running Club Ever at 10:00am for the weekly Saturday Fun Run. We'll split up into groups depending on the turnout for distance and time goals for 4, 6 or 7 mile loops. It's your choice!

What to expect: a seriously fun group of runners who definitely do not take running too seriously . We will meet, chat, RUN, stretch, chat, EAT BREAKFAST and then leave. It's that easy.

Breakfast Details : Between 11:15 and 11:30 (depending on how long we run) we will meet back at City Sports on Comm Ave. near Packards Corner for Pot Luck style brunch.

Contribute to a great breakfast with an item to share with the group (eggs, bagels, fruits, muffins, juice, bacon, potatoes, etc.) You're not obligated to bring anything, though, so please join us for breakfast after the run anyway.

ALL ABILITY LEVELS WELCOME!!!

Secret parking is accessible in the Star Market parking lot (just make sure you walk through Star Market. No one has ever been towed.)

Bring a friend, see you out there.


informalrunning.com


Read the BLOG

results.description:
Hi fellow Social Boston members, 

Don't you like easily meeting new people? 

Don't you love being on the Charles? 

Join us when we canoe and clean the Charles.

We'll be joining one of the most well respected nonprofits theBoston Volunteers. Learn more: Boston Volunteers

We'll be removing the water chestnuts. This species of chestnuts is noxious and asphyxiates native, local wildlife. 

This is one of my favorite volunteer events and we do it only once or twice a year (in the summer before they drop their seeds).

B/c of the limited amount of canoes there are a very limited number of spots for this event. Can you grab a spot? 

We hope you can join us! 

We anticipate volunteering with you, :)

Josh and friends

P.S.  A couple other popular groups will be joining us including: 

Don't you like to help people: Boston Volunteers

Do you live near Brookline: Brookline Area 20's & 30's Adventurers 

Don't you like Adventure: BBoston Adventures

Are you a Foodie: Favorite Boston Restaurants

results.description:
This is a local charity ride that many of our members like to support.

Meeting location:  Panera Bread

Meeting time:  1030 am  .....KSU  1100 am

cost:  $25

We will ride together to the Weymouth Elks

_____________________________________________________________________

Please join us for the 8th Annual Motorcyle Run to raise funds for Joanna's Place. Riders, non-riders and kids are all sure to have a good time!

Tickets are a tax deductible donation of $25 for adults, which include t-shirt and lunch. Kids are free!

******************************************************************

Visit :

Registration Site

 to register and pay for tickets online.  Online ticket sales will close July 3.  

***********************************************************************

The run T-shirts are always a hit and we sell out fast.  To reserve a T-shirt in your size purchase tickets online by July 1.  

You can also buy tickets at the event; exact change is appreciated. 

A 35 mile motorcycle run through the south shore will start and end at the Weymouth Elks Club at 1197 Washington St in Weymouth MA.

Schedule of events:

10-12: Registration for riders. Enter Weymouth Elks via Washington St. Upon arrival in the parking lot you will be greeted by Run Staff who will check you in while still on your bike. If you registered onlilne, provide your name to check in. Otherwise, please pay $25 to the attendant for each rider. Exact change is appreciated. All riders will receive a hand stamp for lunch and a token to claim a T-shirt. Refreshments (coffee, donuts) will be provided inside Elks.

12-1: Riders exit parking lot on Pleasant St side. 35 mile run through the South Shore. Please fuel up in advance as there are no scheduled stops. Run will be escorted by Police bikes. Please provide Police with space to pass at all times.

1-5: The Party!! Non-riders please go to the check-in desk inside the Elks. If you registered online, provide your name to the run staff at the desk. All other adults please pay $25. Exact change is appreciated. Everyone will receive a hand stamp for lunch and a token to claim a T-shirt. Bar opens at 1 and lunch will begin shortly after 1.

Food, DJ, entertainment, and fabulous raffles items will be provided!

Face painting, animal balloons and other fun provided for kids!

Remember your sunblock!

For more information contact Heather at[masked]-5898.

results.description:
This session is a great opportunity for kids (6-17) to learn how to make fun games, stories, and animations using Scratch (a free and easy-to-learn online drag-and-drop programming tool) and for parents to follow along! No prior programming or typing experience is necessary.

This is the first of four summer sessions: Sat July 18th will also be on Scratch, then we switch to Code Combat (a free, online strategy game that teaches kids how to code in Python or JavaScript) on July 25th and August 1. 

We’ll be at the LogMeIn office in the Fort Point Channel area of Boston. The address is 320 Summer Street, Boston 02210. Map: https://goo.gl/maps/vMvDj. There should be some meter parking (bring quarters) as well as a few lots in the area. The nearest T stop is South Station.

If you could please RSVP only for the number of kids attending, it would be helpful for us in calculating our numbers. For example, if you are bringing one child, please RSVP "Just Me". If you are bringing two kids, please RSVP "+1". Be sure to bring a laptop (not a tablet) and charger. If you need to borrow a laptop, please let us know by emailing [masked].

Note: We're always looking for mentors. If you're proficient in a programming language, coding tool, or robotics and are interested in volunteering, please let us know.
results.name: Scratch for Kids - Learn to Make Fun Games, Stories, and Animations!

results.description:
This is the first of four weeks on learning to code with Python, a powerful programming language considered to be an excellent choice as a first programming language. 

Pre-requisite: Kids must have completed a Scratch course (or equivalent) and have at least some familiarity with the concepts of loops, variables, and if-then statements.

Unlike with Scratch, we think folks will have a tough time if they miss any of the four sessions, as each week we’ll build on concepts we have introduced in the previous week(s). Please consider whether you'll be able to attend most or all of the sessions (July 11, July 18, July 25, August 1) before RSVPing. 

We’ll be at the LogMeIn office in the Fort Point Channel area of Boston. The address is 320 Summer Street, Boston 02210. Map: https://goo.gl/maps/vMvDj. There should be some street parking (bring quarters) as well as a few lots in the area. The nearest T stop is South Station.

Please be sure to bring a laptop (not a tablet) and charger. If you need a laptop, please let us know by emailing [masked]. 

We have a maximum of 10 kids, so please be sure to RSVP early and mark your calendars with this event! If you could please RSVP only for the number of kids attending, it would be helpful for us in calculating our numbers. For example, if you are bringing one child, please RSVP "Just Me". If you are bringing two kids, please RSVP "+1".  


Note: We're always looking for mentors. If you're proficient in a programming language, coding tool, or robotics and are interested in volunteering, please let us know.
results.name: Basic Programming Concepts in Python (week 1 of 4) - Please read the prereqs
