results.description:
Come join us at our water training sessions! No prior experience necessary. New paddlers welcome at all times of the season.

Mon & Wed: 6pm - 8pm, meet 5.45pm by the grassy patch near Barking Crab.  
Sat: 11am - 1pm, meet 10.45am by the grassy patch near Barking Crab.

Price: New paddler 2-class pack for $10. All other paddlers paddle unlimited under the $110 annual membership fee. New paddlers who decide to join get a $10 deduction from membership!

Outdoor paddling means exposure to the weather! Be prepared to get wet!

Clothing: Wear workout clothes, synthetic fibers that dry quickly are highly recommended. Bring dry clothes to change into afterwards.  
Footwear: Sandals or flip flops recommended. Some people go barefoot. Shoes and socks are not recommended.  
Other: Bring plenty of water and sunscreen.

All paddling equipment is provided (paddles, pfds). Locker provided on-site.

Please sign our e-Waiver before you get on the water

Hope to see you there!

Lily[masked]

 

In the event of inclement weather, announcements will be made through the comments area of each meetup event, also in Twitter, Facebook and email alerts.

Sign up for our weekly emails and email alerts

Twitter: @Boston1Dboat

Facebook: http://bit.ly/Boston1facebook

 

Parking: Channelside Parking at 284 A Street. Enter at 29-41 Necco Street, off Melcher Street. Weekend $6 flat rate.

Public Transport: Closest T stop is South Station on the red line.

This is a popular ride In Rhode Island. Lines Narragansett Bay at some points, awesome scenery. Providence to Bristol. 14.5 miles one way the entire length. But I am starting at Haines Memorial State Park which gives about a 9 mile ride to Bristol one way (about 18 miles r/t). http://www.riparks.com/Locations/LocationEastBay.html

All flat and paved, all bike types welcome. If you want to start in Providence there is a hill there that you will have to conquer on your ride back to the parking lot. That parking lot is off of Veterans Memorial. This is about an extra 5 mile ride to Haines Memorial. More details to come soon.

results.description:
(Almost) every month, the New England Science Fiction Association (NESFA) hosts an all-day gaming extravaganza at their clubhouse. They have a collection of hundreds of games, ranging from fillers to all-day affairs, and they usually break out 100+ of them for people to choose from. They also have a ridiculously enormous science fiction library their members can check out books from. Mike S. gave me permission to invite ALL of the cube pushers who would like to, to come by and check out the NESFA clubhouse on the game day and play a few games.

Personally, I am trying to get an 18XX set up that day so I can teach a couple of the NESFA members who expressed an interest in it. Getting in some cube pushers would help me be able to introduce it to some new people and speed things along a bit. Be sure to arrive by noon sharp so we can get set up and get going if you want to play 18xx! Otherwise you can drop by anytime, though everyone might be in a long game if you don't come at the beginning. Caveat ludor!


The clubhouse is a great place for gaming and you'll find people with a variety of interests - I'm a basic member, it's pretty cheap for the year, and they even give you free snacks (soda, popcorn, water, and Bill T. frequently brings a big box of Dunkin donuts on game day). There's free parking in the back lot, but it fills up fast, so be on time if you're driving! Or better yet, you can use public transportation (bus lines 80, 89, 101; see http://www.nesfa.org/clubhouse/businfo.html). There are lots of restaurants nearby (Chinese, subs, and pubs) so if you want a bit more than tasty NESFA snacks, you won't go hungry. So come on by, and get to play some great games with some new and old faces.
results.name: NESFA: Monthly Game Day (possibly with 18xx!)

results.description:
Social In Boston Presents:

BOSTON ROOF DECKS TOUR

The Summer of 2015 is going to be a great one for the members of Social In Boston! One part of what makes it so great is our weekly roof deck tour. Each and every Saturday we'll be visiting a different roof deck for food, drinks, relaxation, and socializing. Please the details carefully every week, as the details are going to change. Some venues have better times to visit than others, and as already stated, each week will be in a different location...

Our Fifth Stop...

At Coppersmith, you’ll see accessibility in everything from the bar snacks (spiced Marcona almonds and beef jerky) and appetizers (confit chicken wings and a Bloomin’ Tempura Oyster Mushroom) to shareable family style meals like a pig roast, Moroccan lamb, and fried chicken dinner. Other offerings on Henry’s heavily locavore menu will include farmer’s market salads (some of which will be sourced from a vertical garden on the roof), hand-crafted Agnolotti, a soft shell crab BLT, grass-fed steak tip frites, a classic New England lobster roll, and seafood boils on the patios. On the rooftop deck is an Airstream trailer serving cocktails and raw bar mainstays—think oyster, clams, and crudos.

This roof deck is so new that at the time of this posting, no photos could be found online except for the digital renderings shown here!

GETTING THERE

Coppersmith is at 40 W 3rd Street, South Boston, MA, 02127.

Click here for directions on Google. The nearest T stop is Broadway on the Red Line, which is 2 1/2 blocks away walking.

Parking: There is limited on-street parking if you can find it. : )

See you there Socialites!

~Matt
results.how_to_find_us: Look for us on the Roof Deck! : )

results.description:
The Boston Diamond Way Buddhist Center is pleased to host Diamond Way Teacher Eric Gibson for a special lecture, "Buddhist Meditation for the Modern World", at the Boston Public Library South End Branch.

The lecture will begin at noon. There will be opportunities for questions and answers followed by a guided meditation.

This lecture is part of a larger weekend program in connection with the Boston Diamond Way Buddhist Center (29 Rockingham st, Cambridge, Ma)

For more information about the weekend program please visit:

https://www.facebook.com/events/735361369923136/


Eric Gibson has been a practitioner of the Diamond Way Karma Kagyu Buddhist lineage and a student of Lama Ole Nydahl since 1998. In 2002, at Lama Ole’s request, he began giving formal Dharma teachings and has since traveled through the Americas and Russia sharing his experience. His big heart and joyful style have inspired many people. Eric and his wife Milla live in Minneapolis, MN, where they are active in the local Diamond Way Buddhist Center. He has a degree in Philosophy, and works as a Financial Advisor.

results.description:
(a set of 4 Saturday classes)


Always wanted to learn how they really fought in the middle ages? Forget any ideas about crude battering on armour; the successful warrior strikes to the gaps and the openings of his or her opponent's attacks, and supplements this with disarms, throws, and other techniques which secure the advantage over larger or stronger attackers.

Around the year 1400, Fiore dei Liberi trained medieval knights and squires, and authored multiple books of medieval combat, some of which have survived to the present day. His method, L'Arte d'Armizare (the Art of Bearing Arms), shows an integrated and cross-referenced system of sword, dagger, grappling, spear & lance, pollaxe and other weapons on foot and on horseback, with and without armour, and easily dispels any illusions that medieval combat was about unskilled strength.

Our beginners' course is four linked classes that give the basic techniques and vocabulary of L'Arte, and enables men and women to begin regular unarmoured training and learning.  No prior training needed; all class equipment is provided.

So, come join the scholars and combatants of our company!

(The price shown is for the set of all four classes (July 11, 18, 25, and Aug 1) and membership and registration.  Classes are not offered separately.  We'll send an email with some class materials before the first session.)
results.how_to_find_us: We'll start on the triangle just off the bike path, between Magnolia & Thorndike fields, at the end of the parking lot.

results.description:
Interested in helping to feed the hungry? This is a great volunteer opporturnity for people who enjoy cooking. Its also a great event for meeting people.


After the event volunteers are encouraged to go to the Red Hat (located down the street) for a drink or bite to eat. Note that this is optional.

Event Summary:

12:30pm - 2:30pm Meal preparation & Dining hall
set-up
2:30pm - 3:30pm Meal is served by volunteers to guests
3:30pm - 4:30pm Clean-up

About Saturdays Bread:

Saturday’s/Sunday’s Bread is a program that serves free hot meals to people in need in Boston every Saturday and Sunday at the Church of St. John the Evangelist, 35 Bowdoin Street, Boston. Their mission is to provide healthy meals in a safe and inviting atmosphere, free from Society’s prejudices and judgments. This is an interfaith, interracial, interdenominational activity of people concerned with the hungry in the Boston area.

Over the course of its 25 years, Saturday’s/Sunday’s Bread has served more than 300,000 guests. Directions

Saturdays Bread is located at The Church of St. John the Evangelist is at 35 Bowdoin Street, Boston, between Cambridge Street and Derne Street behind the State House. The entrance to the dining hall is through the door to the right of the main church entrance. Go up the ramp and ring the bell marked "Clayton Hall," not "Church Business" or "Common Room." Please be patient; it sometimes is hard to hear the bell in the dining hall or kitchen.

Parking: Parking is a challenge, so it's a good idea to carpool or to go by T if possible. The on-street parking is very scarce. The closest public parking is the 100 Cambridge Street Parking Garage, which you enter from Somerset Street, one block east of Bowdoin. Parking at the garage is $7.00 for the full day on weekends.

There are a few other small parking lots nearby. The Boston Common Garage, a little further away, is $10 for the full day on weekends.

To reach the 100 Cambridge Street Parking Garage: Coming from Storrow Drive and West, go one block past Bowdoin Street (and past the 100 Cambridge Street building). Turn right at the next light onto Somerset. Coming from Government Center and South/East, turn left at the end of Center Plaza, the large, curved building opposite Government Center. The garage is on the right in the first block. If the auto entrance door is down, please knock; the garage is open Saturdays and Sundays.

Public Transportation: The closest T stop is the Government Center stop on the Green Line. From the subway exit, walk west on Cambridge Street two blocks and turn left on Bowdoin. The walk from the Park Street (Red/Green Line) station is a little longer, but a pleasant walk in good weather. Follow Park Street toward the State House, turn right on Beacon, then quickly left onto Bowdoin.

We charge a $4 dollar fee that is used for SVB's Operating Costs. Meetup posting costs, website, other expenses.
results.how_to_find_us: Please meet the organizers in the kitchen.
results.name: Help Serve a Meal at Saturday's Bread (July)

- Creating a portable access point


- Serving simple web applications using Node.js


- Using general purpose I/O pins to drive diodes


And anything else we can think of. Bring a laptop. Everyone will get a chance to connect to the device and do some programming." -- Jeff Gold


Here are the details:


1. WHAT: Learning trails - Raspberry Pi (Part II)


2. WHEN: July 11th, 2015 (this Saturday) from 1:00 PM - 3: 00 PM


3. WHERE:

We'll meet at the Braintree Library in the small conference room upstairs:


Thayer Public Library

Braintree, MA

a)


https://www.raspberrypi.org/help/what-is-a-raspberry-pi/

There will be no face to face meetup unless we reach 50 RSVPs by Thursday of the week. You must be enrolled in one of the 10 FREE courses below or similar courses. 

Our past experience is that 20% of the RSVP shows up in the weekend meetings. Considering that, unless we have about 50 RSVPs, we cannot have a face to face meeting. Please use the questions / answers / discussions below for now. While asking questions, please make reference to the name of the course and the related module within the course. 

Cousera offers the following classes towards obtaining highly valuable knowledge/skills in Data Science Specialization. It is sometimes hard to work on the exercises and homework without the help of an expert.  Receiving one-on-one help from an expert can improve the commitment of finishing the program with accelerated learning. With that in mind, we are experimenting with the following service.


An expert (MS or PhD in Statistics) will answer any question free that takes less than 10 minutes to solve. There are nominal fees for one-on-one interactive help.  Please use the following link to request for help, or just email [masked] or call[masked]-8864.

results.description:
Revisit the Charles: Where bicyclists played in 1895
Saturday - July 11

Ride Type: Map, Follow the Leader, Intro, Arrowed

Times and Routes: 2:00 PM for 12 miles, with stops at historic sites: about 2 1/2 hours

Leaders: John Allen [masked] until 9:30PM), Larry Finison

Description: Take an easy ride, about 12 miles among bicycle-related historical sites with Larry Finison, author of the acclaimed book Boston's Cycling Craze, 1880-1900. Visit and learn where bicycles were built, where bicyclists by the hundreds hung out and picnicked by the Charles River, and about Waltham's former bicycle racetrack.

Start: Duck Feeding Area, 148 Norumbega Road, Weston

Directions: Directions: From the east on Commonwealth Avenue (Route 30): take the first right at the end of the bridge over the Charles, then turn right again (or else you'll be heading for Route 128...). From the west on Route 30, turn left at the traffic light before the bridge, onto River Road, then take the second right to the Duck Feeding Area. From Waltham, take South Street, turn left onto Norumbega Road: the Duck Feeding area is at the end.

More information and UPDATES: http://crw.org/rides/ride.php?id=84&year=2015
results.name: Revisit the Charles: Where bicyclists played in 1895

Come, share and enjoy the reasons the play, King Lear, is one of the most brilliant plays ever composed by human hand. Brilliant because it is bursting with light, hope, love, forgiveness, reverence, healing, learning, self-knowledge and so much more. Did we say King Lear, oh yes, King Lear indeed, the very same! Just when you thought it was the darkest.

This will get you super ready for the July/August Shakespeare on the Common


If you like, please bring a family member or a friend.


[UPDATES will appear in the comment section]

PROTOCOL

- In a brief and well backed up introduction, your host will redeem this bright side of Lear.

- Following a fruitful discussion, each Shakespearean may solidly defend this or that.

SOME POINTS OF INTEREST

1. The magnificent role of Edgar in King Lear.

2. Is the Fool kind?

3. Wherefore does Cordelia have to die?

4. The resilient role of Kent in King Lear.

5. Wherefore does Lear have to die?

6. Why is life of utmost importance in King Lear?

7. Where is forgiveness in this play?
results.how_to_find_us: Don't miss out, please come to the actual main door, the one with a security personnel (at desk).
results.name: Ecstasy and True Love in King Lear.

results.description:
This is an invitation to discuss Life, to discuss what our Dreams are, to discuss what is stopping us from reaching there and how we envision to be there. 

This is not for the weak hearted. We will hold a sacred space for each of the group member without any judgments or fears. There will be no suggestions to be given - only Listening and Inquiry.

Through the listening and inquiry of other's story, we will serve them to reach their own inner truth and light. At the end of the session, I will give a group healing to those who wish. 

We can go for dinner later if we feel like.

******** PLEASE RSVP only if you can make it. It takes a lot to arrange these Meetups and it's disrespecting to not just show up ********
results.name: Discuss our Dreams, Where we are, Where we want to Be

Close to Boylston on the Green Line, or a short walk from Park Street (Red Line) or Downtown Crossing (Orange Line). 

We traditionally have a large social meetup twice each month. This gives everyone an opportunity to come and make new friends, practice their Japanese or English, and spend time with a bunch of interesting people from around the Boston area and overseas.


Come on by, relax, practice in either language of your choice, and enjoy being part of our growing community!

Whoever is interested generally goes out to Chinatown for dinner afterwards, to eat family style - cost usually around $12-20/person (not including any drinks other than tea/water, for which people pay their own way).

Directions from Rte. 128 (including Boston Rte. 93N to Rte 128): Follow Rte 128 North. When Rte 128 North splits to the left from Rte 95, be sure to stay on Rte. 128 "North to Gloucester". Follow Rte 128 to Exit 22E (Beverly Rte. 62). Follow Rte 62 approx. five minutes to Cabot St. and turn right. We are one block before the Cabot Cinema on the right. Note: After Rte. 95 North and Rte. 128 split (north of Rte. 93) the numbering system for exits changes and exit numbers begin decreasing.

Directions from Boston via Rte. 1 [see above for Rte 93N Directions]: Take Rte. 1 North over the the Tobin Bridge. Follow until you see signs for Rte. 128 Gloucester and Rte. 95 North and take that exit. Bear left to take Rte. 128 North and stay on Rte 128 until Exit 22E (Beverly Rte. 62). Follow Rte 62 approx. five minutes to Cabot St. and turn right. We are one block before the Cabot Cinema on the right.

Directions from Salem: Go over the bridge from Salem to Beverly on Rte. 1A. Just after the bridge bear right onto Cabot St. Travel for 1 1/2 miles till you see Cabot Cinema and Organic Garden on the left.

results.description:
This is a photo walk to capture some of the more unique architecture of Boston's inner city. The main goal for this meetup is to capture buildings in the most unique way possible, not so much straight-on, rather than at steep angles, with your fisheye lens or as a reflection in a show window. Staying until after dark will allow us to capture star trails in the city, which requires focusing on stars as well as some specialized post-processing, which I will explain.

We will meet at the Custom House (the clock tower), see "how to find us" for exact coordinates (paste those into Google maps). From there, we will walk around to shoot at some five to six different locations, ending up at the very unique  Municipal Court Department building, a very cool building with sharp edge, perfect for star or cloud trails. From there, we can return or adjourn, your choice. I will send out or have with me a marching route as we get closer.


Weather forecast is pretty good, temperatures in the high 70s and dropping, cloud cover about 25%, making for good cloud streaks if you bring your ND filters or stay into the night. There will be no moon, making this perfect for star trails after dark. Sunset is at 8:20


Suggested equipment: fisheye, super-wide angle, lens baby, tilt-shift lenses tripod if you want to stay into dark, a remote and perhaps a pad to kneel down and shoot straight up (I use a ~8x10 patch of yoga mat that I carry with me at all times) - bless you if you have an articulating monitor.


Places that we will cover, other than the clock tower are: Leventhal Park, Boston City Hall and Government Center, Winthrop Square, Post Office Square, Liberty Square and the Court Department:

Photos courtesy of Derrick Morin:
results.name: Boston Downtown Architecture (day to night)

results.description:
When I heard they were doing a reboot of Terminator I was like...no way...not interested.  Then I saw the preview which includes Arnie...so now I am all in!  Besides several group members made sure to tell me how much they want to see this flick.

Showtime is 7PM.  I will be at the theater by 6 and we will head in for seats as soon as they let us.  The movie is showing downstairs so I will be at the ropes near the concession stand until/unless they let us into the inner lobby.  It is crazy gathering downstairs so if you want to sit with the group, don't be late! 

Tickets are on sale on Fandango now:

Tickets


In general, I arrive at the theater an hour before the show to start gathering people, and we head in for seats about 30 minutes before the show, so we can sit together. This also allows us to take turns getting snacks, etc., before the previews start.  It also allows for any unexpected, last minute changes at the theater.  Although fairly infrequent, having wiggle room to exchange tickets, etc. is VERY helpful.

Please note, everyone is responsible for buying their own tickets.  And while it is possible to buy your ticket at the door, shows often sell out. I strongly advise you to buy your tickets in advance.  I will announce when tickets go on sale on Fandango. Please do NOT buy tickets until I have finalized the time.

If you miss the group ahead of time, come find us after. We gather in the hallway outside of the theater we just saw the movie in, to discuss the film a bit, allow for restroom breaks and to get a head count of all those who would like to go out after for drinks and munchies.

$$$$Managing the after event is much easier if everyone brings cash, so please plan ahead if you want to go out with the group after.  We will be splitting one bill for the group. No separate checks.$$$

One more thing, please keep your rsvp's up to date so I can plan the after event and know who to look for.  Thanks!

Movie Details:

Release date: July 1, 2015
(3D/2D theaters and IMAX 3D)        
Studio: Paramount Pictures       

Director: Alan Taylor

Screenwriters: Patrick Lussier, Laeta Kalorgridis

Starring: Sandrine Holt, J.K. Simmons, Byung-hun Lee, Arnold Schwarzenegger, Jason Clarke, Jai Courtney, Matt Smith, Michael Gladis, Emilia Clarke, Dayo Okeniyi

Genre: Thriller, Action, Sci-Fi, Adventure

Official website: Terminatormovie.com| Facebook| Twitter| Instagram                  

Plot Summary:

When John Connor (Jason Clarke), leader of the human resistance, sends Sgt. Kyle Reese (Jai Courtney) back to 1984 to protect Sarah Connor (Emilia Clarke) and safeguard the future, an unexpected turn of events creates a fractured timeline. Now, Sgt. Reese finds himself in a new and unfamiliar version of the past, where he is faced with unlikely allies, including the Guardian (Arnold Schwarzenegger), dangerous new enemies, and an unexpected new mission: To reset the future…
results.name: Terminator Genisys (7PM IMAX 3D)

results.description:
Let's go sing our lungs out!

This is Japanese style karaoke which means a small group of friends all together in a private room. DoReMi offers karaoke in 13 different languages and has rooms that can accommodate up to 12 people. Depending on the size of the group we will either all pile into one room or split into two rooms.

Cost

We usually end up spending 3 hours singing. The venue charges by hour and the number of people in a room. 12 people for 3 hours ends up being $16.25 (before taxes), 11 people is $16.36 (again before taxes), 10 people is $16.50, and so on a so forth. The only accept cash so if you bring $20 you should be all set.

Food and Drinks

DoReMi has vending machines with snacks and drinks. They also allow outside food and drinks (with the exception of alcohol) to be brought in. Please feel free to bring your own snacks and drinks to share with the group and we'll have our own mini potluck.

Getting Here

Please check the website below for public transportation options. There is also a small parking lot to the side and behind the building and street parking for those with cars.

DoReMi Karaoke Website: http://www.doremikaraoke.net/

If you have any other questions please don't hesitate to contact me or post a comment below.

results.description:
Let's Play Dodgeball!

Remember when you used to get a lunch break AND recess? Let'slationships were formed while we were playing games-we made friends, scores were settled, and we figured out how to interact with the opposite sex. Well, some of us did :)

https://youtu.be/QPDs4zs3kzw

Remember when you used to get a lunch break AND recess? Let's return to our glory days for some school yard fun! So many relationships were formed while we were playing games-we made friends, scores were settled, and we figured out how to interact with the opposite sex. Well, some of us did :)

Worried about being branded with the logo from the rubber ball? Well, don't...we use soft squishy balls…without a visible logo :) So, if you really hope to get a tattoo, you'll have to find another way.

Dodgeball Details: Teams are chosen round robin style, so it doesn't matter if you ruled the schoolyard at one point. There won't be any awkward "I hope I'm chosen before the kid in the full body cast". The "rules" will be explained by the referee before playing starts. They aren't complex, and there won't be any instant replays for controversial calls.

It's designed to be fun, playful, and casual. The only rule I can remember is not aiming for someone's head. Ladies, I can't guarantee that the guys are going to follow that one : ) Guys, this is still not the best way to get a woman's attention….

All levels are welcome! We will be playing on a padded floor, wearing socks (remember to bring socks!). The arena is air conditioned and is smaller than a typical dodgeball court.

Dodgeball of Boston is located at 1 Broadway in Arlington, MA. There is a small parking lot, emphasis on small, and free street parking available on the side streets. Public transportation is probably the easiest way to get there. It's about one mile from Davis Sq Redline T and Alewife T Stations.

Cost: $10. PLEASE try to pay with a $10 bill, or some combination that adds up to $10 ($5 bills, $1 bills, etc…), as change is hard to make. The cover goes to pay the rent for the space.

After Dodgeball: We will head for drinks/appetizers nearby at:

Orleans Restaurant 
65 Holland Street 
Davis Square, Cambridge

We always have a lot of fun there too, drinking, eating and singing karaoke, and it's a great way to enjoy Friday night!

This will be a joint event with other meet up groups, please only RSVP in one group.

IMPORTANT: Please be sure to bring socks with you in order to play!

--Carla & Matt 
;-)

https://youtu.be/cXmt_iFLd58

results.description:
Fellswater “Boston's premier Celtic music ensemble”
Betsy Ketudat, Fiddle
Jim MacConduibh, Guitar/Bouzouki
Sarah MacConduibh, Irish Flute/Whistle
Andrew McIntosh, Smallpipes
http://www.fellswater.com/


Saturday, July 11, 2015, 8pm
Park Avenue Congregational Church (PACC)
50 Paul Revere Road, Arlington, MA

Continuing our series of Scottish traditional music at the Park Avenue Congregational Church, notloB is very pleased to welcome back for the THIRD time Fellswater, “Boston's premier Celtic music ensemble”. Fellswater is a dynamic instrumental Celtic music ensemble based out of Boston playing a wide range of music from traditional to modern compositions, drawing from the music of Scotland, Ireland, Brittany and Canada. Fellswater has delighted audiences at New Hampshire Highland Games (2010, 2012, 2014), Blackstone River Theatre (2012, 2013, 2015), Club Passim (BCMFest 2012) and Colonial Williamsburg (2014). The band will be performing at the Royal Nova Scotia International Tattoo in 2015. Fellswater has released two well-received albums, "Fellswater," and "Thursday Night." The band features Betsy Ketudat on fiddle, Jim MacConduibh on guitar and bouzouki, Sarah MacConduibh on Irish Flute and whistle, and Andrew McIntosh on smallpipes.

results.description:
Let's step out of our comfort zone a bit and try something different. We will ride the T, photographing some of the more interesting stations and people along the way. That's right - we will be shooting people! No pretty landscapes on this shoot.

The rules:

1. No tripods

2. Shots must be on, in, or of some part of the MBTA 'T' system.

The cost:

If you already have a T pass, you are all set.  Otherwise, check out the MBTA website for pricing: http://www.mbta.com/fares_and_passes/.  I recommend purchasing a 24 hour pass at a station kiosk for $12.

Parking

There is street and garage parking in the area.  Consider parking at the extremities of the T routes (Wonderland $5, Forrest Hills $6, Braintree $7, etc.). it's cheaper, and you can plan your shooting according to your route back to your car.

Service Alert: Busses will replace Blue line service between Maverick and Orient Heights, so there's a delay for us North Shore folks  

Travel light. You could do well with just a single lens in the 35-50 range (full frame), or 22-30 (crop). Of course, feel free to bring super wide to long tele if you feel like lugging all that gear around. Fast apertures are needed - f2.8 or better. A 50mm f1.8 or f1.4 would be ideal. Bring less gear and use smaller lenses to help remain inconspicuous while shooting people.

Some challenges:

Motion blur: even slow moving trains and people can be blurred with shutter speeds around 1/8.

Candid moments: Be patient and inconspicuous. Wait for expressions and interactions. Shoot from the hip - don't be obvious.

Ghosting: Yes, this can be done without a tripod!

I will provide some tips for slow shutter shooting before we start.  I am not limiting the group number, so we should spread out in small groups.  Some stations I expect to visit include: Park Street, Charles MGH, Harvard Square, Downtown Crossing, and South Station - certainly more.

The photos below are from a project from a few years ago - I couldn't find the color images, but B/W works too!
results.name: No Tripod Challenge:  Shooting on the T

http://www.fellswater.com/

Saturday, July 11, 2015, 8pm
Park Avenue Congregational Church (PACC)
50 Paul Revere Road, Arlington, MA

Continuing our series of Scottish traditional music at the Park Avenue Congregational Church, notloB is very pleased to welcome back for the THIRD time Fellswater, “Boston's premier Celtic music ensemble”. Fellswater is a dynamic instrumental Celtic music ensemble based out of Boston playing a wide range of music from traditional to modern compositions, drawing from the music of Scotland, Ireland, Brittany and Canada. Fellswater has delighted audiences at New Hampshire Highland Games (2010, 2012, 2014), Blackstone River Theatre (2012, 2013, 2015), Club Passim (BCMFest 2012) and Colonial Williamsburg (2014). The band will be performing at the Royal Nova Scotia International Tattoo in 2015. Fellswater has released two well-received albums, "Fellswater," and "Thursday Night." The band features Betsy Ketudat on fiddle, Jim MacConduibh on guitar and bouzouki, Sarah MacConduibh on Irish Flute and whistle, and Andrew McIntosh on smallpipes. 

Meet-up before for dinner. If you are interested, please comment below to express which of the two restaurants you prefer:

results.description:
Kick up your heels with us at our smoldering Summer Oasis Dance Party!

Intro Group Lesson begins at 8:00pm (optional, but a wonderful way to break the ice with fellow dancers!)
Party begins at 8:30pm

$5 per person

Join the studio as we continue our Second Saturday Social Series: our monthly ballroom dance socials held on the 2nd Saturday of every month. All experience levels and ages welcome, and no partner required! Smart-casual to Elegant attire encouraged.

Check out our FAQ's below for more info.

Star Dance School
323 Washington Street
Brighton, MA
[masked]
[masked]

StarDanceSchool.com

----------------------------------------------------------------
Ballroom Dance Social FAQ's:

What is a “Ballroom Social”?
A ballroom social is a dance party featuring ballroom dance styles. Music is played for Standard and Smooth styles such as waltz, foxtrot, and tango as well as Latin and Rhythm styles including salsa, rumba, cha-cha, and the like. At Star Dance School Socials an optional 30 minute group dance lesson kicks off the evening as well!

What on earth should I wear?!
Smart-casual to elegant attire is encouraged, but most importantly wear clothing you can move around in comfortably. If you do not have ballroom shoes often a light weight dress shoe will do the trick. *Note: Please avoid sneakers or metal spike-heel shoes as they can damage our floor. Thank you for your understanding!*

Do I need a partner?
Partners are welcome, but not required to enjoy a night out on the town with us! Social dancing is a fantastic way to make new friends and we encourage dancers to rotate partners in order to meet new people.

Do I need prior dance experience?
Whether it is your first time dancing or you have years of ballroom under your belt, all levels are welcome to attend our socials!

results.description:
Lets explore one of Boston's Inner Harbor Islands - Georges Island. The 39 acre island is comprised of two drumlins. Originally used for agriculture for 200 years until in 1825 the US Government acquired it for coastal defense. Over the next 20yrs Fort Warren was constructed. Upon completion, the forts defensive design was virtually obsolete. The fort served as a training ground, patrol point, and Civil War prison. After 100yrs of Military use, the fort was decommissioned in 1947 and acquired by the Metropolitan District Commission for the historic preservation and recreation in 1958.

Lets see if we can find "the Lady in Black" the ghost of a Confederate prisoner's wife who is said to have been sentenced to death for aiding in an escape after disguising herself as a male soldier, and hanged in a black robe which was the best he soldiers could do to accommodate her last request of being executed in female clothing. The myth brought attention  to the need for preservation and protection of Fort Warren and inclusion in Mass State Parks and eventually National Park System.

What to bring: flashlight/flash for lighting the dark corridors and creating our own images of where the Lady in Black resides, tripod, various lenses.

Purchase tickets on-line for $17.00 at https://ticketing.bostonharborcruises.com or through the Boston Harbor Cruises website. The ferry leaves Long Wharf at 9A. Responding to this Meetup does not guarantee availability of ferry ticket -- book in advance to ensure passage.

results.description:
Hi beautiful member!

What could be more special and memorable than greeting the Sun in the morning and doing your refreshing QiGong on a sandy beach on a summer day?

Or practice QiGong in the open grassy field surrounded by green forest?

The idea of summer outdoor classes at the Lake Quannapowitt and organizing a group class at the local beach in Manchester-by-the Sea turned into an exciting project of having a QiGong Tour around a few wonderful places.

So the summer schedule has changed as I tried to figure out better times for all.

What does QiGong Tour mean?

It means some exploration, some easy hike/walk and QiGong exercises at the quiet places where Nature is fully aligned with your intention of creating harmony and a beautiful flow of Qi in your body.

So, here is the invitation for you to join our group (beginners are welcomed) for a great QiGong experience.

Bellow you will find the list of places where our outdoor QiGong practice will be offered during July and August.

In case of rain, a class will be canceled and you will be notified.

Register for this QiGong Tour by emailing me and confirm your coming one day before. 

If you need a ride, I'd be happy to organize it for you. Just let me know!

I hope our group will be big enough to gather more Qi and share a huge amount of summer fun!

I believe you are enjoying this summer and getting plenty of vitamin D from the Sun to prepare yourself for the colder seasons. Stay healthy and optimistic. Life is GOOD!

~Angela

July 16th, Thursday, 5:30pm - Horn Pond, Woburn, MA (meeting at the parking lot)

results.description:
Bolstered by the boom in shipping, wealthy industrialists made Newport their summer vacation spot and built opulent country ‘cottages’ down lantern-lined Bellevue Avenue. Modelled on Italianate palazzos, French chateaux and Elizabethan manor houses, and decorated with priceless furnishings and artwork, they remain the town's premier attraction – which are among the most important in the US.


The Newport Mansions have 4.6 average rating on TripAdvisor, are a top New England attraction on Lonely Planet, and alleged to be among the beautiful pieces of architecture near Boston. Come join us for a day exploring Rhode Island's most beautiful village and yachting center.

We'll meet in the Porter Square parking lot by Panera to meet up and carpool. Please be prepared to chip in for gas with your car owner (or ZipCar costs). If different cars prefer to meet in different places, we could potentially meet in other places.  We'll make the 1.5 hour trek to Newport across, spend the day with the 5-mansion tour package, have a picnic lunch, and should be back by 5pm.

Come with your lunch packed! We can grab additional food as well, but since the transport and tickets will probably add up, this is a way to save a bit of money.

Tickets are $32.99 and can be purchased at the mansions. For more information, check out the site: http://www.newportmansions.org/

Please RSVP if you plan to come. If you RSVP, I'll be waiting to hear from you, so please show up, or let me know if circumstances change! If you ditch us without warning a few times, we'll have to remove you from the group. If you need to get a hold of me, my number is four four zero 488-5055.
results.name: Tour the Newport Mansions

results.description:
The MGA's seasonal handicap tournament is coming up soon! Newcomers to the game and old hands alike are welcome to play. The location is about a 15 minute walk from the Davis Square Red Line station and is located in the basement of a condominium on a side street off of Mass Ave. Parking is also free on Sundays.

Check-in starts at 9:45 and play begins at 10:30. There will be four rounds of play with 45 minutes of main time and and 25 move/5 minute byo-yomi. All games will be handicapped and are AGA rated.

Registration fee is $20 for MGA members and $25 for non-members. Pre-registration is encouraged and gets you a $5 discount, to pre-register email me at [masked] or send me a message through meetup. Make sure your pre-reg includes your name, your AGA number if you know it, and the strength you will be entering the tournament at.  You can pay either at the door or through the MGA's paypal account at http://massgo.org/tournaments.html

Prizes are:
$50 First Place Prize
$30 Second Place Prize
$20 Third Place Prize

All other proceeds go to support the local Go infrastructure.

Pre-register soon and mark your calendar for an awesome day of Go!

Questions? Comments? Just drop me a line.

Public speaking with ease and impact in front of any group.

Imagine standing in front of any audience, feeling absolutely confident and at ease.

Whether you have public speaking anxiety or simply want to express yourself with greater clarity the experience in a Speaking Circle® will guide you toward effortless authenticity

Speaking Circles help:

Business professionals become more effective, authentic and powerful. 

People expand their vision of what life could be like when they are able to

be fully present, confident and authentic. 

People who suffer from stage fright to overcome their fears.

Hope to see you soon,

Dexter Nardella

At a Speaking Circle you are provided all the support you need to express yourself in your own time and in your own unique way, without fear or discomfort. Some call this depth of expression, “speaking from the heart,” “the authentic self” or “your real voice.” Whatever you call it, you know when you are there; you know when someone else is there.  Click to read FAQs about a Speaking Circle.

results.description:
This event opens to rsvp'ing 10 days in advance.

The trail is 8.5 miles from Arlington center to Bedford and we ride at a moderate pace.This event auto-repeats monthly and may be leaderless.

Lunch afterwards at Not Your Average Joes, 645 Mass Ave.

Suggested donation $1 for Meetup fees.

This ride happens only if its a nice, clear day above 40 .

Wear a helmet, bring water and sunscreen, watch out for children on the trail, and have a good time!

 

The Minuteman Bikeway passes through the historic area where the American Revolution began in April 1775.

Today, the Minuteman Bikeway is one of the most popular and successful rail-trails in the United States, enjoyed for both healthy recreation and transportation.

The bikeway has become a new type of “Main Street” where neighbors and strangers alike come together while riding, walking, or skating on the path.

In 2008, Rails-to-Trails Conservancy inducted the Minuteman Bikeway into the national Rail-Trail Hall of Fame.

results.description:
Come and join us for open board gaming at Excelsior!  They have a large gaming area to seat approximately 50 gamers in addition to a growing board game library that patrons may take right off the library shelf and play at-will.  They have also dedicated their Sunday schedule for just this open board gaming event, so us board gamers will have the pick of the tables during the entirety of the event which happens to run the entire time the shop is open on Sundays.

Attendees are welcome to bring in their own games or use games from the library.  Bobby will also run game demos during the event in case you want to learn a new game or simply try before you buy.

In case you are interested in purchasing the game from the demo session, Excelsior will offer 10% off the price of purchasing a new copy of that game that day on top of the 10% discount they are offer to all MBG members (for a total discount of 20% off).  If for some reason they are out of stock of the demo game and must special order it for you that day, they will order it for you and allow you to take an additional 10% special order discount on top of the previous two discounts for a total discount of 30% off!

Want to special order something that is not the demo game?  Add the base TGA 10% discount and the 10% special order discount together for a total of 20% off any special orders.

Nourishment:  The shop carries various snacks and non-alcoholic beverages if you need something to snack or sip on while you game.  For more substantial food, there are many eateries located within walking distance from the shop on Main Street.

Parking:  Excelsior has an agreement in place with the Jiffy Lube at 3 Powder Mill Road.  Attendees may park in the lot behind the Jiffy Lube building.  From there, it is a short walk across Powder Mill Road to the Excelsior's door on the corner of Powder Mill and Waltham Street, which is the 4-way intersection closest to Jiffy Lube.

results.description:
Annually, The Boston Portrait Photographers proudly collaborate for a good cause. This cause for the past several years has ranged from serving injured veterans upon their return home from overseas, aiding families of those veterans with financial assistance, providing housing modifications and so forth. Through organizations like the Semper Fi Fund and Veterans Advocacy Services, we like to proudly say we support those who preserve our freedom. This year will be our biggest effort yet. 40 Pin Up style models will be posing for photographers at this year's Rockabilly-style cookout benefitting Veterans Advocacy Services. They will be posing on motorcycles, hot rods as well as in the serene back drop of the pond and gazebo area of the Maynard Rod and Gun Club. Come and join us on a day that is family friendly, full of fun and patriotism as we collaborate . Hair + make up is provided for Pin Up Models. Information for this event is as follows:

A motorcycle bike run, rockabilly-style cook out and family - friendly summer bash with honored guest speakers and awards for tattoos and motorcycles. All funds raised to benefit the Veterans Advocacy Services www.veteransadvocacyservices.org

There will be food, raffle prizes and live entertainment . Veterans Advocacy Services is a non-profit focused on specialized and individual care for veterans according to their specific needs.

Photos by event photographer, Iggy Barskov.


It is a group based out of Massachusetts who lives by the statement "Leave no Veteran Behind" . When: Sunday, July[masked]
Where:  12:30 Maynard Rod and Gun Club, Inc. 45 Old Mill Road Maynard, MA

Professional Photography provided by: Iggy Barskov www.iggyphoto.com

Live Music and Entertainment provided by : The Silver City Band

Admission: $20.00 donation to the Veterans Advocacy Services . Photographers pay this donation as their admission and receive a wristband so that they may take photos !

This year we will give a special tribute to the late SPC Nicole Elizabeth Ortiz . She had served in the United States Army National Guard and was deployed to Iraq in 2004.

Ortiz had passed away in September of 2014. She would attend each annual fundraiser and bike run and was a veteran lost too soon . We welcome her friends and family to join us at this year's event for a cause that she felt was very important to support.
results.name: The Great Pinup Shoot: Benefitting Veterans

results.description:
This is the new, regular meetup on Sundays at noon at Brooklyn Boulders in Somerville. Look for the dark-haired guy with glasses and yellow Katana climbing shoes who keeps falling off the bouldering wall. I'll have my stuff on the first table/bench thing by the entrance. I primarily boulder, but hopefully we'll get a good variety of climbing interests coming so that everyone can follow their climbing passion!

(Credit to Francesco Cardiello for the information below):
BKBS is the gorgeous, new, state-of-the-art climbing gym most convenient to those in the Boston, Cambridge, and Somerville area. Although pricier, it features 60+ feet toproping and lead climbing, a massive 22 x 140 foot bouldering wall (and there's still another upstairs), yoga & fitness classes, a sauna, awesome water fountains that fill your water bottle, a retail store, lounge area, weight room, and a soon to open cafe! There's even a collaborative work space where you can study, work, and climb!
If you are looking for a partner or just want to get your climb on join us on Wednesdays for a fun time.

FAQ:

How do I get there? BKBS is conveniently located within a 10 minute walk of the Porter Square station. Walk down Somerville Avenue and turn right on Properzi way and head all the way down. It is also very bike accessible. If you drive, you can find the lot at 30 Dane St. It is located next to Artisans Asylum.

Why should I do this meetup? Since BKBS is such a new community (opened in late July 2013) few people have developed regular climbing partners to train and climb with. This is a great opportunity to meet other climbers interested in BKBS. Climbing is an inherently social sport - to top rope and do lead, you need to meet people who are dedicated to climbing. The Wednesday meetup assures you'll meet a partner to regularly climb with. We are looking to expand to other nights in the future.

What if I haven't climbed before? First off, don't be intimidated. Everyone started somewhere. If you have never belayed before, please make sure to take the Learn the Ropes class. More info can be found here: http://www.bkbsomerville.com/Classes/. If you have a working knowledge of how to belay, you will need to be belay certified before using the walls. Please flag down a BKBS employee and let them know you need to take a belay test. To pass such a test you will need to display how to tie a double figure eight knot with a fisherman's backup, safely belay a climber up a wall, catch them on a fall, and lower them to the ground safely.

What equipment do I need? You will need at the bare minimum a harness and climbing shoes. Rentals are available. Grigri devices are provided at every station.

What if I can come, but at a different time? Just let everyone know you want to climb at a different time and use the community to find a partner for those dates / times.

These are the climbing rates:

ADMISSION (Full day use, you can leave and come back!): Day Pass - $22 (Students $18)
10 Pack - $200 (Students $169)

RENTALS: Shoes - $5
Harness - $5
Chalk Bag - $2
Full Gear Kit - $11

results.description: SoulCollage® Come for an afternoon of creativity and community for your soul.  Hundreds of images are provided for you to create you own "deck" of cards using glue and 5x8 mat board.  Express your passions, your inner "personalities", your shadow sides, the stuff of life you love! Create meaning and metaphor using images from nature, the world of animals, great ads with gems, interiors showing ways to depict passages or life journey. A journaling process provides a way to deepen the meaning of your cards. We also use the cards for "divination"... asking a question and selecting a card from someone else's upside-down deck. There is always an answer in the card! Held in a sunlit sanctuary with soft music.  Very relaxing.  Express your Soul!  All materials supplied, including a huge stash of amazing images.  The event runs 1-4 pm.  New to SoulCollage®? See samples at www.AHigherBalance.com

results.description:
On June 27, the Humanist Hub’s board of directors, staff and selected volunteer leaders held the first-ever Hub Strategic Planning Retreat; a key topic was how we, as a community, should respond to Humanism’s “identity crisis.” With a larger nonreligious population than ever comes greater opportunity for communities and organizations to represent the interests of the freethinking population. But the challenge of determining who exactly we are, and what an organization for us should do or be, is also increasingly confusing and complicated.

How do we strike the right balance between secular and humanist? Between being a safe space for atheists, or agnostics, or our religious allies? How political should we be? How much should we emphasize ritual? How do we effectively welcome people from a huge range of different backgrounds...and personality styles? In other words, how do we decide when to connect, when to act, and when to evolve-- not to mention, when to criticize religious beliefs or stand up for the rights of the nonreligious? 

Never waste a crisis, Rahm Emanuel said early in the Obama administration. And after 15 years as an active humanist, Greg believes this is the time to move toward greater clarity...or at least, to admit our ambivalence! Join us for a talk, discussion, breakout groups, food, and hanging out. 

PS: Notes from the strategic planning retreat will be shared in the coming weeks, but only with formal Hub members. You can join any time, it only takes a few minutes and a major financial contribution is not required (visit humanist hub.org to sign up). 

PPS: Thank you for all the requests to hear Greg’s talks online. Though we haven’t made the recordings available yet, they will all be incorporated into his next book, and we’ll also keep you posted when we do post them!
results.name: Greg Epstein: Humanism's Identity Crisis

Summer is finally here, so let's head back to the Salem Willows! Let's enjoy a fun Sunday afternoon playing skee ball, arcade games and eating ice cream. It's been a few years since we did this and it was a blast last time.

Background and history:

“One of Salem ‘s Treasures!”

Fun & Games: Historic 1866 carousel. Modern video arcade. Kiddie rides & classic Skeeball. Prizes and treasures. Vintage pinball machines.

Good Food: Salt water taffy. “The best popcorn in New England”. The Willow’s famous chop suey sandwich. Pizza, fresh seafood, and homemade ice cream.

Great Park: Picnic in the shade of majestic, 200 year old white willows. Play on the beach. Fish from the public pier. Enjoy outdoor concerts.

Real History: America’s first ice cream cone. Joseph Brown’s flying horses. Duke Ellington. A public park since 1858. A special place in history.

Free Parking & Admission! 

Not T accessible. 

Rain reschedules. 

Driving Directions to plug into GPS: Use 167 Fort Ave, Salem, MA 01970 

Website: http://www.salemwillowspark.com/

See you there,
Phaedra and Alex

results.description:
Dear Urban Sketchers.
As we are just over the summer solstice, it is a great occasion to have a new outdoor workshop!
In this particular workshop you WILL NOT need any drawing materials except paper. That's right JUST PAPER!

The idea is using materials from nature for sketching.
You will be drawing with espresso coffee

and henna,

and you will learn how to carve your own tools from fallen tree branches.

This workshop takes place in the Boston common as this site has weeping willow trees which are the ideal wood for our purpose.

Our schedule will be as folllows:

1-Picking the right branches (no worries, we love trees and won't hurt them! we will be usen the dry branches that we can find laying under the trees as it is very important that they are DRY, for carving)
2-I'll give you a tutorial on carving your instrument.
3-We will use your espresso coffee (get it at Dunkin Donuts or Starbucks)
4-We will be using henna pigment as well (I provide that)

What to bring:

1-A sketchbook, surgeon gloves (if you want to draw with henna, as it stains the skin! or you can use stick to espresso.)
2-An X-acto knife and a plastic bag for peelings scrap
3-Tissue paper
4-A watercolor tray
5- Please wear clothes that you wouldn't mind to get coffee stains on

The first hour will be instruction and collecting wood.
The following hour will be sketching.
We are extending our meetup extra 30 min for show and tell since we will be busy!

Handouts will be provided as in our previous workshop.
Join us, bring a friend and let's have fun!!!

**This is a FREE WORKSHOP, donations are always welcome to keep bringing you workshops like this, and meetup website costs**
results.name: Draw with Henna and Coffee! & making your own pens WORSHOP!

results.description:
CHECK IN AT 2:30, put your backpacks in the lockers, get your tickets, and Meet & Greet then at 2:45 we're OFF! 

DON'T be late!!  If you're late we meetup  at (see details below). I understand that parking in Cambridge on Sundays is unrestricted. This event is also co posted with another Meetup group. 

Following this we'll head to join the follow up Social event at the Sinclair (or alternate rain location TBA) , details follow.

For the 5th time, at this popular & incredible gem of a Museum meetup location we meet just inside the main entrance & head (this time) strait into the main Surrealist gallery. The first art you will see to your left is Detroit Queen. Then we loop around back to the last gallery in that area containing some great masterpieces of the 19th century. 


Host will be waiting there so we can regroup at 3:20 PM. If you are late meet us there.

Then we head upstairs  to the 2nd floor (we won't visit the other floors above) -- go to the elevators or take the stairs there where we'll head down the hall where the painting of the wounded Amazon is. (To get to that, take a left from the elevators then left again). Forging ahead, we'll check out the mini Bernini statuettes, then the room of the Madonnas and their babies. By now you'll know who is in the Meetup so try and stick with the group. But hosts should be your main guide to not losing the group. NOTE-- host will not linger at some of the galleries but pass through because there will be MUCH  MUCH MORE to see after this.

If you do lose us or get tired, look for others in the meetup at the cafeteria back on the first floor, where we gather again and leave by 4:45 to go to The Sinclair patio (there will be an alternate venue if rain). The Sinclair event is separately posted also with Social Fun.

ADMISSION free for Cambridge residents with a drivers license and Cambridge library card. Otherwise it's $15. Backpacks not allowed. You can store them in lockers across from the admissions area, alternately there is another locker area down one floor from there.
results.how_to_find_us: Just inside the main entrance at 2:30

results.description:
Here's the link to the online location:

http://www.gratefulness.org/labyrinth/index.htm

Hope you enjoy it as much as I have!

Remember that in the labyrinth the 3D rules relax. Time, space, extraneous noise and interruption are altered as we move toward center. This creates a personal, sacred space, a high frequency bubble of awareness that allows your stress to be transformed by the laws of resonance.

   This interactive model gives you multiple options. You  may use your mouse to move the cursor or you may choose to allow the program to do that for you. Either way, you may follow the mouse with your eyes or a finger. Close or cover one eye... and follow with the other:  you access & enhance the opposite side of your brain. Do the same with the other, then perhaps, both. If you are using your finger to follow the cursor along the path use one finger the first time... use the same finger on the other hand next time. Again, this accesses different parts of your brain and brings clearing & energy to that part that is being stimulated. This translates into clearer neurological pathways, clearer energy meridians in your body and opportunities for greater insight, stronger connections to your own intuition and spirit.

  Before your 'walk, you could smudge, light a candle, say a prayer, call in the Four Directions, invite your angels or guides to be present with you on the path.... Set your intention if you wish, ask your guidance to show you what you need to know, or what is standing in your way. You might ask  to understand and  release an illusion that is keeping you from a relationship or abundance in your life.

   As you return from center, you may invite understanding, knowing, peace to fill your awareness. 

   Take time for yourself after your 'walk'. Have some water handy. This kind of vibrational/energy work allows the body to transmute and release long held concepts, belief forms, illusions from their resting place in cellular memory to be transformed into energy that supports you instead of weighing you down. Just as if you did yoga or had a massage, your body may release and clear pure water will support the process.

   Even in an interactive online labyrinth... you are never alone... If we all walk at 3 on the 2nd Sunday... we walk together. And always, even when it seems we are walking alone, or not...  our guides & angels are there.

   Will be posting a couple of holiday events... hope to see you in 3D soon. Peace, Deb

The Inner Engineering online program includes guided meditations, powerful breathing techniques, and deeply engaging discourses about the nature of the mind and practical wisdom to manage life’s situations.

Inner Engineering is a combination of methods derived from the ancient science of yoga that addresses every aspect of human well-being — from your body, mind and emotions to the essential life energy within.

This 1 hour introduction to Inner Engineering explains the fundamental approach of the program in a live setting that offers you the opportunity to ask a trained Isha teacher questions about the program and practices available.

“Inner Engineering is neither a religion, nor a philosophy or dogma; It is a technology for wellbeing. One does not have to believe or disbelieve, you just have to learn to use it. Technology will produce results irrespective of who you are.” – Sadhguru

results.name: Second Sunday Meetup

results.description:
Hello ASL Enthusiasts!

WHAT: ASL Weekly Social
WHEN: EVERY SUNDAY 
TIME: 4:00-6:00PM
WHO: ANYONE is welcome to come by and have a conversation in ASL
WHY: To socialize, have fun, and enjoy chatting in ASL
WHERE: Tavern in the Square in Porter Square

NOTE: Every once a while, the location may change. PLEASE look on the website each week for confirmation. THANKS!


To get to the Meetup, take the RED LINE stop OUTBOUND TO ALEWIFE, and stop at PORTER SQ. Look down the street. There's Tavern in the Square! If you're driving, you can park on the street for free on Sundays!

Anyone who loves ASL is welcome to come and be part of the fun! We want to warmly extend an invitation to Deaf people or others fluent/skilled in the language (CODAs for example) to join our group.

This is an easy-going, casual, ASL get-together to meet people who enjoy American Sign Language, who want to brush up on their signing skills, and want to learn more ASL by using it as often as possible.

We strive to have a good time and communicate without using voices. If we need to, we draw or write what we don't know how to sign, and if lots of folks show up, we split up into small groups and mix and mingle, so we can actually see one another clearly, face-to-face and get a good conversation going.

Don't be afraid or shy if you're not "perfect" at ASL, because being "perfect" is not the point of this group. No one expects that everyone will be at the same level, and none of us mind slowing down or repeating what we have signed so that everyone understands.

We all laugh WITH one another as we fumble along, mess things up, and start over again. This isn't an ASL class, since none of us are certified ASL teachers, so there's really no pressure or expectation--other than that we all use ASL to communicate. We all learn from one another!

IF you've taken an ASL/Sign Language class before (or have had exposure to someone who uses the language) and know the basics (alphabet, numbers 1-20, and even a small vocabulary of signs ), then join us to get your fingers, hands, face and body moving, ASL-style!

IF you haven't taken an ASL class, or don't know the basics, don't be discouraged ... you can come along anyway and learn by watching, and gradually, participating. We have lots of resources that we can suggest for learning ASL from a qualified teacher or authentic source, such as books, online classes, and local classes at various locations near Boston.

If you can, "officially" RSVP, even if the RSVP is "No," so that we know who is definitely going to come.

It will be great to see folks!

Erika and Jack
results.how_to_find_us: We will be there signing our beautiful language to inspire all of you!
results.name: ASL WEEKLY SOCIAL

results.description:
Join other single professionals for an early evening happy hour, topped off with about* 7-10 rounds of "mini-dates." You'll meet each member of the opposite sex for 5-7 minutes each (depending on the size of the event), turn in your dating card and then we'll send you the contact info of your mutual matches 48 hours later. On average, 80% of those who attend end up with at least one or two mutual matches.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

PAYMENT POLICY:
$24 (MUST register with code ATWYS- codes can not be applied after registration)

REGISTER AND PAY HERE: 

https://2015bostonatwysspeeddating.eventbrite.com

(SEE MORE FAQ's BELOW)

ABSOLUTELY NO REFUNDS FOR LAST MINUTE/DAY OF CANCELLATIONS. NO EXCEPTIONS.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


FAST FACTS - PLEASE READ:

*We can not accept payment at the door for these events. All registrations must be done online via the Eventbrite link below before the event. No exceptions.

*RSVPing through meetup does not guarantee admission. You must pre-pay to secure your spot in the event.

*Business casual attire requested. No sneakers, t-shirts or active wear, no ripped jeans.

*We limit our events to 12 couples/24 people. (See reason below)

*You will have approximately 8-12 dates.*

*Matches are tabulated and emailed to attendees 48 hours after the event.

*Event lasts about 90 minutes give or take 10 minutes between check-in and all speeddating rounds. Speed rounds last 5 minutes each.

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

*There are no refunds for cancellations, late arrivals or no-shows.

*You must arrive and check in within 20 minutes of the advertised start time.

OUR METHOD:

Online dating is great. But how many times have you chatted with someone just to have them fade or never make plans to meet? How many dates have you had that you thought went well and then ended up confused because you never heard from that person again?

The upside of online dating is that it provides us with so many options. The downside is that people start to believe that their options are endless, which leads them to move on quickly seeking that "perfect" match.

This is where speeddating comes in. To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's 1 or 2 more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. We will NOT host an event if there isn't AT LEAST 7 of each gender registered, and we will NOT let there be an excessive (more than 3) amount of one gender versus the other.

PLEASE REMEMBER:
* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.
results.name: Speeddating Ages 39-49 - 1f/3m spots left

results.description:
This is an ongoing weekly (donation only) class for anyone, offering experiential practice in meditation, along with an opportunity to be among others interested in deepening spiritutual practices.  The class provides you with a felt sense of your own divinity; your Higher Self. The meditation, based on Kriya practices,  is partly guided, partly silent. In the guided part we open up to the flow of golden light and energy that is always pouring down to our body/mind/heart and being. Accessing that flow and inviting it to fill us brings a profound level of openness, while washing away limiting thoughts, feelings and beliefs. This higher vibration of unconditional love serves to open our consciousness to new levels of peace, joy and awakening. Bringing the flow of light into the body/mind/heart means we more consciously embody our Light Being, so we are more present, happy, forgiving, peaceful and joyful while in the world.
   After the guided portion we spend time in peaceful silence.  Whether you are an experienced meditator or a beginner, you will love the sweetness and powerful energies of this group. At the end of the class we make time for questions or sharing.  Group meditation is powerful, and it's refreshing to be among fellow travelers!
   Judy also teaches the Sound and Light meditation; a way for you to draw your senses inward to open your spiritual eye and to hear the sounds of your chakras. 
   This practice is non-denominational, appropriate for anyone. 
   Held in a lovely healing space, just walking in will bring you instant peace.  All are welcome.
    You may also want to check out my other Meetup, for a variety of spiritual programs:  http://www.meetup.com/Evolving-Beings/

results.description:
"She generally gave herself very good advice, (though she very seldom followed it)." --from Alice's Adventures in Wonderland


Weary of her storybook, one "without pictures or conversations," the young and imaginative Alice follows a hasty hare underground--to come face-to-face with some of the strangest adventures and most fantastic characters in all of literature.

The Ugly Duchess, the Mad Hatter, the weeping Mock Turtle, the diabolical Queen of Hearts, the Cheshire Cat--each more eccentric than the last--could only have come from that master of sublime nonsense, Lewis Carroll.

In penning this brilliant burlesque of children's literature, Carroll has written a farcical satire of rigid Victorian society, an arresting parody of the fears, anxieties, and complexities of growing up.

PS. We will probably read (and enact) some famous passages, so come prepared to be your favorite character.

results.description:
Join other single professionals for an early evening happy hour, topped off with about* 7-10 rounds of "mini-dates." You'll meet each member of the opposite sex for 5-7 minutes each (depending on the size of the event), turn in your dating card and then we'll send you the contact info of your mutual matches 48 hours later. On average, 80% of those who attend end up with at least one or two mutual matches.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

PAYMENT POLICY:
$24 (MUST register with code ATWYS- codes can not be applied after registration)

REGISTER AND PAY HERE: 

https://2015bostonatwysspeeddating.eventbrite.com

(SEE MORE FAQ's BELOW)

ABSOLUTELY NO REFUNDS FOR LAST MINUTE/DAY OF CANCELLATIONS. NO EXCEPTIONS.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


FAST FACTS - PLEASE READ:

*We can not accept payment at the door for these events. All registrations must be done online via the Eventbrite link below before the event. No exceptions.

*RSVPing through meetup does not guarantee admission. You must pre-pay to secure your spot in the event.

*Business casual attire requested. No sneakers, t-shirts or active wear, no ripped jeans.

*We limit our events to 12 couples/24 people. (See reason below)

*You will have approximately 8-12 dates.*

*Matches are tabulated and emailed to attendees 48 hours after the event.

*Event lasts about 90 minutes give or take 10 minutes between check-in and all speeddating rounds. Speed rounds last 5 minutes each.

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

*There are no refunds for cancellations, late arrivals or no-shows.

*You must arrive and check in within 20 minutes of the advertised start time.

OUR METHOD:

Online dating is great. But how many times have you chatted with someone just to have them fade or never make plans to meet? How many dates have you had that you thought went well and then ended up confused because you never heard from that person again?

The upside of online dating is that it provides us with so many options. The downside is that people start to believe that their options are endless, which leads them to move on quickly seeking that "perfect" match.

This is where speeddating comes in. To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's 1 or 2 more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. We will NOT host an event if there isn't AT LEAST 7 of each gender registered, and we will NOT let there be an excessive (more than 3) amount of one gender versus the other.

PLEASE REMEMBER:
* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.
