venue.address_1: Carpenter Center for the Visual Arts 24 Quincy Street Harvard University
venue.name: Harvard Film Archive

results.description:
House of Bamboo

Directed by Samuel Fuller. With Robert Ryan, Robert Stack, Shirley Yamaguchi
US 1955, 35mm, color, 103 min

Assigned to remake Fox's 1948 crime filmThe Street With No Name, Fuller transported the story of underworld racketeers to postwar Tokyo and Yokohama and joyfully seized the challenge of filming one of the first major Hollywood productions shot on location in US-occupied Japan. House of Bamboo is a brisk and violently beautiful tale of love and betrayal made vivid by bold expressions of Fuller's signature graphic style (an assassination in an ofuro tub, a gunfight on a rooftop amusement park) and extraordinary use of iconic Japanese locations, from Mount Fuji to gaudy pachinko parlors. The twin poles of the taut drama are Robert Ryan and Robert Stack as competing versions of steely and scarred masculinity, each with a secret vulnerability flickering beneath their shells of brooding bitterness that hint at a dark past. Fuller adds a subversive element by making House of Bamboo a kind of love story between men, with the gorgeous Shirley Yamaguchi caught somewhere in between.

As this is a work night, there will not be a Meetup after the film for discussion.  This film is part of HFA's Sam Fuller retrospective.  We will post several of his films, with many opportunities for After-Film Discussion.

See you at the movies,

John
results.how_to_find_us: We can gather at the Grafton Street Pub, hopefully outdoors, at 5:00 for dinner and discussion of Sam Fuller
results.name: HOUSE OF BAMBOO

results.description:
Come join us for our second Meetup!  For those who weren't able to make the first one, for those who would like some reinforcement in what they learned the first time, and for the curious, this is for you. 


     We'll go over some of what was covered in the first meetup, and then go into other areas.


     We'll cover the basic ideas, that the cravings are primarily caused by the processed foods we eat, and what it is in them that causes us to react in such an out of control way. 


     We'll talk about the cost--in terms of weight, health, lost opportunities in the job, relationship and romance department--of not making a change.

     We will talk about the way out:  the avoidance of these foods.  We'll discuss other and healthy, delicious options instead, and how to ease into them.  (Or go cold turkey, if you prefer!)

    We will talk about food as an addiction.  And not just any food, certain types of food have the characteristics of addictive substances.

     We will discuss how a whole foods plant based approach, as best as any of us is able, is the most reasonable and effective way to address your situation. 


     Even if you plan to continue to eat meat, there will be a lot of material that will help you.  For the healthier a diet you have, the healthier YOU will be!

     And every participant will receive not only a weight loss resource guide, but a free report entitled "What The Diet Experts & Gurus DON'T Know".

     See you then!

Al

(by the way, the member from the first Meetup, who was--how shall I put this politely--aggressively and offensively opinionated, has been removed from the group)
results.name: Let's Continue To Get Acquainted!

group.name: Curb Those Cravings!  Healthy Eating = Healthy Weight Loss!

results.description:
Hey gang! Let's use this show as an actual chance to do a MeetUp-style MeetUp! If we get more than 10 people RSVP'd here, we can get someone to stake out a corner of the lobby with a sign so we can all meet up and chat/eat/drink/etc. Let's make a night of it!

America's another year older, school's out, and food is still just as healthy as laughter according to a man I met on the subway who was wearing a stethoscope!

Chris Duffy (You're the Expert) and Kevin Seefried are excited to invite you out for a night of food samples, chuckles, and maybe even LOVE. (Probably not love, but who knows? What if you find yourself sitting next to the one and BOOM TasteTest Comedy just changed your life in a moment)

Tickets for these shows always go FAST. In past months we've had writers for Totally Biased w/ W. Kamau Bell, Niki and Sara Live, and Reductress, the winners of the past two Boston Comedy Festivals, and comics who've appeared on Last Comic Standing, CONAN, and the Late Late Show.

This month featuring:
Matt Donaher (CONAN) 
Myq Kaplan (Letterman, Comedy Central)
Kelly MacFarland (Top 100 on Upcoming Season of Last Comic Standing!)

In the meantime, grab your tickets while you can! Just $12 for some killer local snacks and even better comedy from some of our favorite comics on the East Coast!

Tickets available here: http://www.eventbrite.com/e/taste-test-comedy-tickets-15620735039

group.name: Parents & Babies of Boston and Beyond

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.
results.name: Monday Lunchtime Soccer (OUTDOOR)

results.description:
Dear Boston Culture Lovers,


Let's dance Salsa In the Park! 

Salsa in the Park is a series of free, outdoor Salsa dancing, lessons, music, and performances in the courtyard/playground  park at the Blackstone Community Center in Boston's South End neighborhood.  Two to three dance floors are set-up for each event.

***

FEATURES OF THE EVENT


• FREE 30-minute lessons for all levels on all floors from 6 pm - 6:30 pm (and again only for beginners at 7:15 pm on one floor)﻿


• Social Dance to the best Salsa & Bachata music provided by DJ Hernan and fantastic guests 

• Performances throughout the evening by amazing local and national performers varying in music and dance genres.

http://mmsalsainthepark.weebly.com/about-salsa-in-the-park-sitp.html


***

Just a reminder, this is an actual meet-up event, not an advertisement. Please only reserve "YES" if you are definitely attending and intend to meet members of the group. If you reserve "YES", we will be expecting you.  If you reserve "YES" and then have a change of plans, please update the attendance reservation.  A consistent history of not showing up for events may cause you to be removed from the group.  


The meeting time for the Meet-up Group is 5:45 pm at 50 West Brookline Street, the entrance to the dance venue.  The plan is to meet and gather at this meeting point and then go into to the park for the 6 pm dance lesson.  

Since this event will be a somewhat crowded and roaming , it will be very difficult for latecomers to connect with the group. If you are late, I can not guarantee that you will recognize me or fellow members or we  to be able  recognize you from the crowds.  Once the event starts, I put away my smartphone and concentrate on enjoying the event with fellow group members.  

Please plan ahead and allow a little extra travel time to this event. 


I look forward to enjoying this event with the group.

Joana

***

MORE EVENT DETAILS

BAG CHECK AREA


If you have items with you, don't worry! We have a Bag Check area where you can safely leave your belongings with one of our MM staff(donations appreciated and encouraged). And if it rains, we'll dance inside at the Blackstone Community Center!

PARKING: 

On-Street parking available on Shawmut Avenue and Washington Street

PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION:

Orange line to Back Bay, exit Dartmouth Street side (it's about a 10 minute walk). Take a left on Dartmouth St and continue walking a few blocks until you cross over Tremont St. where Dartmouth St becomes W. Dedham St. Continue on W Dedham and then take right on Shawmut Ave. and the first left onto W. Brookline St. The center, courtyard park and basketball courts are on your left.

Silver Line (SL4 or SL5 - Washington St line): Get off at the E Newton St. stop. You will be on Washington St. If you were coming from Dudley and towards Downtown you will continue in the direction the bus is going for one more block, and take a left at W. Brookline; walk down and the basketball courts, courtyard park and center are on your right. If you were coming from Downtown towards Dudley, you will walk back one block, and take a left on W. Brookline as described above.

Take Bus #1 down Mass Ave. (from Harvard or Central Square). Get off at Washington St, and take a left (heading towards downtown, away from Roxbury). Continue to W. Brookline St., and take a left; walk down and the basketball courts, courtyard park and center are on your right.

http://mmsalsainthepark.weebly.com/about-salsa-in-the-park-sitp.html
results.how_to_find_us: at the entrance of 50 W Brookline St
results.name: Salsa in the Park - Free Outdoor Salsa Dancing and Lessons

results.description:
Come join us at our water training sessions! No prior experience necessary. New paddlers welcome at all times of the season.

Mon & Wed: 6pm - 8pm, meet 5.45pm by the grassy patch near Barking Crab.  
Sat: 11am - 1pm, meet 10.45am by the grassy patch near Barking Crab.

Price: New paddler 2-class pack for $10. All other paddlers paddle unlimited under the $110 annual membership fee. New paddlers who have purchased the $10 intro pack get a $10 deduction from $110 membership!

Outdoor paddling means exposure to the weather! Be prepared to get wet!

Clothing: Wear workout clothes, synthetic fibers that dry quickly are highly recommended. Bring dry clothes to change into afterwards.  
Footwear: Sandals or flip flops recommended. Some people go barefoot. Shoes and socks are not recommended.  
Other: Bring plenty of water and sunscreen.

All paddling equipment is provided (paddles, pfds). Locker provided on-site.

Please sign our e-Waiver before you get on the water

Hope to see you there!

Lily[masked]

 

In the event of inclement weather, announcements will be made through the comments area of each meetup event, also in Twitter, Facebook and email alerts.

Sign up for our weekly emails and email alerts

Twitter: @Boston1Dboat

Facebook: http://bit.ly/Boston1facebook

 

Parking: </a>Parking: <a href="http://www.fortpointpier.com/info.php#DirectionsParkingPortage">Channelside Parking at 284 A Street. Enter at 29-41 Necco Street, off Melcher Street. Weekend $6 flat rate.

Public Transport: Closest MBTA stop is South Station on the Red Line.
results.how_to_find_us: We meet on the grassy patch between the Children's Museum & the Barking Crab Restaurant
results.name: Monday Water Training

results.description:
NB: If you want to attend this event, note that since October 2013, Microsoft NERD center requires photo IDs when people sign in. Without showing a government photo ID you will not be allowed to access the NERD center.

There have been some amazing advanced in chip technologies in recent years from the Tegra (nvidia) to the SnapDragon (Qualcomm). We have some new technologies that are going to knock your socks off. 

Rough agenda:


6 - 6:30:  Networking and Pizza

6:30 - 7:20:  Three Speakers

  (1) Andreas Olofsson, Adapteva: A massively parallel, low power chip for vision.

  (2) Joe Bates, Singular computing: Low power vision through approximate computing.

  (3) Gaurav Chaurasia: Halide. Automatic expert optimization of algorithms.

7:20 - 7:30:  1 min pitches from audience. Need help? Looking for a job? Let us know. 

7:30 on:  More networking.
results.name: Making vision go fast and low power

results.description:
Are you looking to get out, meet new people and learn one how to salsa dance? This is the event for you! MetaMovements Dance Company has FREE salsa lessons in the park every Monday night during the summer. It is an awesome time and a great chance to get out and practice your moves. No experience necessary, as there are beginner lessons. Already know how to dance? There is also an intermediate lesson to work on your skills. Even better - this event is completely FREE! I'll be hosting this event every Monday night during the summer. 

The event runs from 6:00-9:00 every Monday night. Get there a few minutes early to meet up with the group and the FREE lesson. We will head out for post-dancing drinks after the event. 

More information from the site:

Back by popular demand, MetaMovements Dance Company, the Blackstone Community Center, and several other supporting sponsors set out for the 5th consecutive year to launch Salsa In The Park, a series of outdoor salsa dance and youth programs in collaboration with the cities of Boston and Cambridge.


Created to decrease crime in the area, provide dozens of summer jobs for high school students, and to improve the overall livelihood of the community, Salsa In The Park offers a stimulating cultural and learning experience for everyone to enjoy in a safe and friendly outdoor environment. 

Last summer, Salsa In The Park attracted over 500 people every clear Monday night to the Blackstone Center, including children of all ages, families, adults, and senior citizens, not to mention Boston’s leading Salsa dancers, creating an empowering sense of community and positive, healthy energy.
results.name: Salsa in the Park (SITP) & Drinks

results.description:
PURCHASE TICKETS HERE: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/sumo-bot-class-tickets-17590688222

Lowell Makes presents a fun an exciting introduction to robotics, Sumo Bot. This class has two parts: Day 1 (7/13/2015): A 4 hour instructional class where all participants will build and program an autonomous robot from our Sumo Bot kit. Everyone will leave with a basic understanding of robotics and a working autonomous robot on which they can continue to experiment and learn. Day 2 (Date TBD): We will hold a Sumo Bot competition where class participants will compete for fun and bragging rights. This class will be an introduction to autonomous robotics where participants will build and program an autonomous robot. After the class, everyone is encouraged to bring their robots home and make improvements (within the Sumo bot rules). There will be a two week period to change your robot and make it the best Sumo Bot you can make before the competition. There are no programming, electrical or mechanical pre-requisites to take this course. You will experience the basics of:

Programming using Arduino
Electronic sensors (range finder and infrared detector)
3d printing
Electrical wiring and trouble shooting
Autonomous robotic algorithms


The price of this class includes a complete robotic kit which allows you to build a working mini Sumo Bot that complies with the Unified Mini Sumo Bot rules. The robot will be very basic and the participants are encouraged to make electrical, mechanical and software upgrades. An open hack-night will be held between the class and the competition to help those who have problems and questions. Robotic experts will be on hand to help troubleshoot and answer questions.

Members of Lowell Makes may attend this class for $60.
results.name: Sumo Bot Class

Register Here: http://eWebinars.com/9778/fgmsh3xgk/webinar-register.php?trackingID1=XXXXXXXX&trackingID2=YYYYYYYYY&landingpage=default&expiration=default

Most real estate agents have 2 revenue streams:

1. Working with buyers to purchase a home for them to live in and

2. Working with sellers by listing and their home.

Learn how to add additional revenue streams to your real estate business by attending this lunch and learn event hosted by Tom Cafarella of Ocean City Development. The presentation will focus on adding additional revenue streams to your real estate brokerage business including:

1.Making money by helping us acquire properties: Think it would be easier to approach an expired listing or FSBO with an offer in hand from a cash buyer? We'll show you how to easily get in front of more sellers.
2.Our Automated Short Sale System:Learn how to capitalize on short sales while keeping your sanity. Our automated short sale program allows agents to spend a very limited amount of time and effort while maximizing their commissions.
3.Buyer Lead Overflow:we don't work with buyers, but that doesn't mean you shouldn't. Learn how working with an investor can provide you with an overflow of buyer leads and how we generate these leads(mostly by accident).
4.Learn how to make money by wholesaling properties & raising capital: we'll show you how to easily and effectively add these two revenue streams to your real estate business.

As an added bonus, we will be reviewing our best practices and systems to allow you to leverage your time and efforts in 2015.

Tom is a principle of Ocean City Development and is head of acquisitions. Tom has been on the front lines of Ocean City Development's team, and has acquired over 62 properties to fix and flip over the past 12 months

Register Here: http://eWebinars.com/9778/fgmsh3xgk/webinar-register.php?trackingID1=XXXXXXXX&trackingID2=YYYYYYYYY&landingpage=default&expiration=default

results.description:
A discussion about the challenges, myths and misconceptions about PTSD and Anxiety.   Kate will tell you her story and then encourage others to share theirs. 

Kate will discuss early recognition and natural ways of relieving symptoms with herbs and oils and Unlike EA (Emotions Anonymous) where you are told to believe that you are powerless over your emotions; here you will be encouraged to take responsibility for them in some cases and to hold them up in front of you so you can examine it closely.  In a safe and confidential environment with others who empathize with you so that you can gain the courage to explore.  This is a peer group not a professional therapy/medical group. 

Many probably have never been diagnosed but are certainly experiencing the affects/symptoms of it.
Get clear and take responsibility for your choices and stop blaming yourself for the choices others have made so that you can prevent it from ever happening again and move on, and stop denying your symptoms and learn to protect and comfort yourself to prevent anxiety leading to panic.

Day and time will be determined by the participants.
Comment below with time/day you are available.
Location will be revealed.
results.name: PTSD - Anxiety Support Group

results.description:
Dr. Alan Grossman :
Bacterial sex and the spread of antibiotic resistance

Join us on July 13th at 7:00pm at the Burren, for Science by the Pint.

Bacteria are everywhere. Some cause infections, and these bacterial pathogens are becoming increasingly resistant to antibiotics, threatening our ability to treat disease. Other bacteria are beneficial and essential for human health. They populate almost every surface on our body, and many within. Our bodies contain more bacterial cells than human cells. Bacteria are also important in the production of many foods (e.g., yogurt and cheese) and can help decompose all types of organic matter – for example, decomposing dead plants in forests.
Despite being single-celled organisms, bacteria are remarkably complex. They are capable of communicating with each other. They can transfer genes to other bacteria, conferring new traits onto their neighbors. The rampant spread of antibiotic resistances in bacterial populations is due to this “sharing,” or transfer of genes from one organism to another. The ways in which bacteria acquire new genes, including those of antibiotic resistance, are topics of fervent study in microbiology research. Among many other important problems, Dr. Alan Grossman and his lab at MIT are interested in understanding: how bacteria talk to each other; how they transfer genes from one organism to another (sex); and how they prevent or minimize transfer of genes (contraception).

Science by the Pint is sponsored by an organization of Harvard graduate students called Science in the News.  In between their sleepless hours of hard work at Harvard Med School, they bring cutting edge scientific research to the public in a fun and informal format. 


The Burren is located on Elm Street right in the heart of Davis Square, just a short walk from the Red Line stop.  If you prefer to drive, there are metered spots on the street and in nearby municipal lots (see link below).  Meters are active until 8:00 PM, and metered spots are free thereafter. Municipal lot meters are good for three hours, and street spots are good for two.

Links:

Grossman Lab website

SITN Facebook Page

SITN: Science by the Pint

The Burren

Davis Square Parking
results.how_to_find_us: Meet in the back room starting at 6:30.  Lecture starts at 7PM.  I will (possibly) be wearing a nerdy Meetup pin graciously on loan from Doreen.
results.name: Science by the Pint: Bacterial sex and the spread of antibiotic resistance

results.description:
One evening at the café-théâtre in 1973, an editor from Éditions Stock who happened to be in the audience asked his waiter if the playwright was in the house. "C'est moi," was the waiter's reply, and with this fortuitous encounter, Gómez-Arcos soon found himself with a generous advance and a contract to write a novel in French. Although at first it seemed to him a farfetched proposition, his career as a novelist would soon be launched. he flew off to Athens to write in seclusion, returning to Paris months later with a full-length manuscript in his arm bearing the title L'agneau carnivore (The Carnivorous Lamb). It won the Prix Hermès for the best first novel of 1975--ironically, the year of Franco's death.

Taken from the Introduction.
results.name: The Carnivorous Lamb - Gomez-Arcos

results.description:
Climbing MeetUp at MetroRock Gym in Everett. Toprope, sport leading, and bouldering available, including some tall walls up to 55 feet. Whether you're a new or experienced climber, join us for a fun and solid workout! We usually have people at all levels. Gym meetups are also a great way to make more friends for outdoor climbing. Plus Mondays are ladies night: discounted admission. If you'd like to lead climb, don't forget to bring your rope :)

*** If you are new to MetroRock Gym and/or climbing, please see the FAQ below. ***

Meet at the picnic tables near bouldering area (the one furthest from the cubbies if available) from 7 - 7:10 PM.  (NOTE: In the rare case the Event Host doesn't arrive within this time window, assume major traffic jam or other catastrophy, ask others nearby to find the group, make introductions, and go climb).  If arriving later, just come find us on the walls.  Hopefully you can recognize us, the event Host(s) (see RSVP list) from our profile pictures, and/or check the small Whiteboard near the bathrooms and water fountain, for a description of what we're wearing that day.

Full-access Day Pass:  $22.  Students, Military or Bouldering-Only Pass:  $18.  Mondays are Ladies Night:  Women's Pass $14 after 3 PM & also special class pricing.

For membership, gear rentals, and other programs and pricing available, or for directions, check the gym website:  http://www.metrorock.com/

Frequently Asked Questions for Newbies:

Q) How do I get to the gym?

A) See website for directions: http://www.metrorock.com/ If you're driving here for the first time, it can be tricky to find MetroRock Everett, especially in the dark! Use a GPS if possible. MetroRock is in a building opposite Boston Coach.   If you don't have a vehicle, the gym offers a shuttle service from nearby Wellington T Station; call the gym for schedule details.

Q) I've never climbed at MetroRock Gym before, what do I need to do?

A) You'll need to take and pass a belay test for rope climbing. There is a separate test for toproping and sport lead climbing. For toproping, if you are not confident you can tie a re-threaded figure-8 knot and double fisherman's backup knot and safely belay a climber using an ATC device, it is highly recommended you take the Level 1 Safety class. They will not allow you to climb on ropes without passing a belay test. Call MetroRock in advance to reserve your spot in the class, and ask them about any discounts or special prices they are offering. Also, you can rent basic climbing gear (harness, shoes, belay device, etc), if needed, at the gym.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet at the picnic tables near bouldering area (the one furthest from cubbies if available).
results.name: MetroRock Monday

results.description:
For July we're reading Stitches: A Memoir.  Sounds interesting. Stray Toasters turned out to be a bit harder to find/pricier than I'd thought, and I don't feel like I can ask the group to shell out ~$50 for the book or fight for the ~3 copies at the library. You should all totally read it though! With no deadline, 3 copies is plenty to go around!

Anyway, I'm really excited for Stitches too.


The time is 7:00, until further notice, rather than 6:30; unless it causes problems we're keeping the new time

The Bumf:

David Small, a best-selling and highly regarded children's book illustrator, comes forward with this unflinching graphic memoir. Remarkable and intensely dramatic, Stitches tells the story of a fourteen-year-old boy who awakes one day from a supposedly harmless operation to discover that he has been transformed into a virtual mute―a vocal cord removed, his throat slashed and stitched together like a bloody boot. From horror to hope, Small proceeds to graphically portray an almost unbelievable descent into adolescent hell and the difficult road to physical, emotional, and artistic recovery.

If you plan on coming, once you've read the book please post one discussion question in the comments for this event. I'll bring a list of them with me, and as usual we'll have them there to draw from when we're looking for stuff to talk about. I won't turn you away if you don't, but let's make running these things a group effort!

For those who haven't been to the Comic Book Club before, it's pretty simple - we sit around, order some food and some drink, and we probe deep into the merits and meanings of our chosen book or books. I also bring along a list of questions (written by you!) to give the discussion a bit of structure - but don't worry - it's pretty casual!

The venue is the Friendly Toast, which is a very casual kinda place with plenty of room where we can easily be heard. Please note though, that it's best to bring cash - although supposedly their card minimum has been relaxed - perhaps even obliterated!
results.how_to_find_us: We gather on the couches in the front beforehand, and once we have a quorum we get a table -- usually one of the booths or the tables in the very back if it's a large group. Ask the staff if you can't find us!
results.name: Stitches: A Memoir by David Small

results.description:
Join us for an introduction to this unique Japanese martial art. Participants will all get a chance to practice some basic movements, explore a bit of the underpinning philosophy, and experience seated meditation. In short, we will have fun together learning about this martial way, one unknown to many in the United States. 

Shorinji Kempo is a relatively new martial art. It was founded just after WWII as part of a Zen Buddhist practice. Today, while the martial art has been separated from the religion, the practice of Shorinji Kempo remains true to it's Zen Buddhist roots, with philosophy and meditation still integral to the study in the dojo of hard (punches, kicks and blocks) and soft techniques (releases, joint locks and throws).

Brand new or frequent inventor? Entrepreneur launching a great idea? From twinkle in your eye to patents to overseas procurement to licensing your idea, we support and help you. Doors open at 6:30 for socializing; meeting begins at 7 PM.

Speaker today is Gastón de los Reyes, co-founder of SPF Innovations which develops, patents and licenses new products and processes for biopharmaceutical manufacturing. Learning his trade at Millipore and Waters Associates, he developed new products in filtration and purification for life science labs, semiconductor processing and biopharmaceutical manufacturing. Gastón will share lessons learned and offer advice to aspiring entrepreneurs.

IANE, Inventor's Association of New England meetings are free to members with a suggested small donation for visitors at the name badge table. Annual membership is $40 per year. Every month we have interesting speakers and topics. Each June we have a members +1 social at a suburban location.

Our usual meeting location is at MIT, building 4 just to the East of the Dome. There is free street parking along Memorial Drive, Vassar St. or Ames St. On Google maps, zoom in on MIT and the building numbers will appear, so you'll know where to go. The Dome is Building 10, behind Killian Court, and building 4 is to the right. Leave at least 10 minutes to walk from your car to the room. The area is amazingly safe to walk at night; the MIT students don't know when to stop so are always around.
results.name: Inventor's/Entrepreneur's Meeting & Speaker

This is the meetup for the July 13th IndieCade jurying session only. MAKE SURE TO BRING A COMPUTER TO COMPLETE YOUR REVIEWS ON-SITE IF POSSIBLE.

IndieCade's International Festival of Independent Games is having four special jurying sessions for board games at its Boston Board Game Hub being hosted at Knight Moves Cafe in Brookline. Jurying entails playing board games, then reviewing the games via IndieCade's online system. Qualified jurors must have experience with designing games that have been exhibited or published (including self-publishing), in academic games research and teaching, or game writing.

Jurying sessions will be held at:

Knight Moves
1402 Beacon St
Brookline MA 02446

results.description:
Join fellow LGBT folks for some informal bowling! The score isn't important - having fun and enjoying the company is! We usually have a wide range of abilities attend.

One of our semi-monthly bowls (the second and fourth Mondays of the month) - we'll be getting together at 7:30 at the Woburn Bowladrome in downtown Woburn (http://woburnbowl.com/index.htm).

The Woburn Bowladrome is located at 32 Montvale Avenue. They are just up the hill from Main Street and Route 38. You can get to the bowladrome from Route 93 by taking the Montvale Ave exit (Exit 36) or from Routes 128/95 from the Winn Street exit (exit 34). The bowladrome is near MBTA Bus 134 from Wellington Station. See below for more detailed directions/info. Parking is available in a large municipal lot behind the bowladrome and there's a back entrance to it from the lot. (The lot is the best place to park - there's little street parking nearby).

VERY IMPORTANT NOTE: Parking can be difficult! Please allow an extra 15 minutes to park, as you may need to wait for a space.


RSVP:

By 5:30, day of event. If you forget to RSVP, you can still come (and should!) - I can *almost* guarantee you'll get to bowl (so far they've always had extra lanes available when we've been going, but...?)


MEETING PLACE:

By 7:30 - Inside the Woburn Bowladrome. Look for us by the counter in the middle, between the two sets of lanes.


COSTS:

To be split among the group: The bowladrome charges $3.00 for shoe rental and $24 per hour ($12 per 1/2 hour) for bowling, with a $12 minimum (pricing is per lane). We've been averaging around $9-$11 per player lately, including shoes.

I am not currently asking for an event fee to cover Meetup's charges, but donations are welcome (max $1 a month). :) (I may take another look at this after the group's been running 6 months.)


DIRECTIONS:

If you're unfamiliar with downtown Woburn, I strongly recommend you print out a map of Woburn center before setting off, especially if you're following the directions from Route 128/95 North below. (There are a couple of quick moves you'll need to make around the common downtown.) A Google map is at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Main+St+@+Montvale+Ave/@42.4788298,-71.1425755,16z/data=!4m7!1m4!3m3!1s0x89e375abd656d707:0x2df321e83b3fdbdf!2s32+Montvale+Ave!3b1!3m1!1s0x89e375a96f6a0ad1:0x8eaf8f6e39ae9811

From Route 93 North: Get off at Exit 36 "Montvale Avenue, Woburn/Stoneham."

Turn left at the bottom of the ramp (towards Woburn).

Go approximately 1.6 miles - you'll see Walnut Street on the right and a dip in the road. Slow down and turn right at the Crest View Plaza building - the roadway leads to a municipal lot in back. There's a back entrance to the Bowladrome from the lot.

If you overshoot the right turn above, you'll pass the front of the bowladrome on your right - taking three rights around the block will lead you to Walnut St and the lot.

From Route 93 South: Get off at Exit 36 "Montvale Avenue, Woburn/Stoneham."

Turn right at the bottom of the ramp (towards Woburn).

Go approximately 1.6 miles - you'll see Walnut Street on the right and a dip in the road. Slow down and turn right at the Crest View Plaza building - the roadway leads to a municipal lot in back. There's a back entrance to the Bowladrome from the lot.

If you overshoot the right turn above, you'll pass the front of the bowladrome on your right - taking three rights around the block will lead you to Walnut St and the lot.

From Route 128/95 North: Get off at Exit 34 "Winn Street, Woburn/Burlington."

Turn right at the bottom of the ramp.

Follow Winn Street 1.7 miles until it ends at Woburn Common.

Take the required right turn - immediately get to the left and take the left around the common.

Immediately get into the middle lane and go straight through the traffic light (up the hill) - onto Montvale Ave.

The bowladrome will be on your left, followed by the Crest View Plaza building - there is a roadway just past them that will take you to a municipal lot for parking. The bowladrome has a back entrance from the lot.

MBTA Bus 134: Leaves the Wellington Station busway at 6:10, traveling through Medford and Winchester before getting to Woburn Square at approximately 6:45 (about 45 minutes early). A later bus leaves at 7:00, which gets to Woburn Square at approximately 7:35. If you take the later bus, be sure to send me a message so we can save you a space (see "your host" below). Note that I or someone else would have to give you a ride back - the last bus back inbound to Wellington leaves Woburn Square at 8:09.


YOUR HOST...

Will be Chris - the six foot tall guy with the beard (see pic). If you're running late or are lost, you can call or text me at  [masked] (Note this new cell number - and that every now and then it doesn't get coverage at my home.) My email is [masked].

results.description:
This summer series of Irish set dancing classes is for beginners who want to learn the basic movements of set dancing while getting a feeling of accomplishment by dancing whole sets through from beginning to end each night. These are good refresher classes for fairly-new dancers, as well, or "improvers" who want to get more familiar with the various sets. 

We welcome more experienced dancers to join in the classes, as well, but the focus is on teaching beginners; in fact, it really helps the new dancers enjoy the classes more when they have a partner who knows the steps already. We all love sharing what we know and there is great satisfaction in helping newbies learn set dancing.

We teach basic footwork and movements to specific sets during the 8 weeks of classes. We teach one set per night, figure by figure, then dance the whole set at the end of the night. By the end of the series of classes, the new dancer should have enough experience and confidence to join in any set dancing group and start to really enjoy the social and physical benefits of Irish set dancing. 

No partner is needed. Leather-soled shoes are recommended, or shoes that don't stick (most sneakers will stick), as set dancing has a lot of gliding movements. Wear comfortable clothes (think cotton t-shirts and loose pants).

The cost is $8.00 per class* - pay as you go - no need to sign up for the whole series. [*$7 per class for Harrington's regular set dancers] 

Frank and Eileen have been enthusiastically teaching beginner summer classes for several years and will continue to teach the classes, but we also have special guest teachers this summer.
results.name: Sliabh Luchra with Alana - Beginner Irish Set Dance Class at Harrington's

results.description:
(Please note: many of the friends who attend regularly are not Meetup members, so there are always more people attending that it says on the Meetup site.)

About This Meditation Meetup

We sit in silence for around 45 minutes, followed by discussion for around 30 minutes or so. The silent sitting is interspersed with some meditation instruction, perhaps a brief reading, a little simple inquiry, exploration or movement. Sitting posture is relaxed, either on a meditation cushion or a bench. It's not a rigid practice- move whenever you need to!

We meet every Monday night, 7:30 pm at the Cambridge Friends Meeting House. The Friends Meeting House is located at 5 Longfellow Park, Cambridge, MA 02138 You can find a very good map here: <a href="http://www.fmcquaker.org/FMC-Map_2006.pdf" target="_blank"></a>

http://fmcquaker.org/about-friends-meeting-at-cambridge/directions/

Parking is available after 6:00 in the loop off of Brattle St. that leads to the Friend's House, and there is a small lot in back of the Friend's House for those with limited mobility. After that, parking is a little tricky in Cambridge (lots of "resident only" signs), but you will find available parking on Mount Auburn St. near Friend's House and on Brattle St. as you head away from Harvard Square.

Coming by the T is a great option, with the Friend's House being a lovely 15 minute walk out of Harvard Square.

If you find you are running late, come anyway! The format is very relaxed and open— anyone interested in contemplative practice is welcome!

 

About Open Awareness Meditation Group

At the heart of these meditation sessions is the silent exploration of what we refer to as Open Awareness. We all know what it means to feel closed, limited, vulnerable, or separate. What is it like to allow ourselves to return to our natural condition of openness, presence, non-separateness and ease? This is what we explore in our meetings.

We have been meeting for over a decade, and those who lead the meditations have known each other and been practicing together for many years. They have all deeply explored a variety of traditions— for some it has been the Tibetan Buddhist practices of Dzogchen or Mahamudra, for others it has been the Indian traditions of Yoga, or Advaita, or what is currently referred to as Nonduality (some popular examples of this are Francis Lucille, Rupert Spira, Eckhart Tolle and Adyashanti). 

However all of these traditions ultimately point to the same truth, the truth of our basic awareness or presence which is beyond any tradition, practice or teaching. This is the presence we share, and the presence we are, beyond words. This is what we explore in our meetings.

This group is unique in that there is no specific guiding teacher, lama, or guru. We all meet as equals to question, share, and inspire each other to explore the Open Awareness we most deeply are. The meetings are suitable for newcomers as well as experienced meditators, and all are very welcome.
results.name: Open Awareness Meditation Group Meetup

Sign-up for the Webinar at: https://www.innerengineering.com/online/free-meditation-webinars-2?signinsrc=Meetup-NewEngland

***REGISTRATION closes 45 minutes prior to the webcast.***  Please make sure you sign-up on our website at least 45 mins prior to the webcast to receive your live log-in link via email. 

(Technical Support:[masked]) 


Isha Kriya Guided Meditation-

A lot of people find it really difficult to calm the mind and settle the body for meditation when they first try it. Too many people get frustrated and give up on meditation before they can experience its many benefits.

These 1-hour guided sessions offer a simple, but powerful kriya practice that aligns your mind, body, and inner-energies to easily and naturally become meditative. Once meditative, your experience of the life within you and the world around you becomes much deeper and richer. Daily activity becomes effortless and joyful. 

You can easily learn this 12-to-18 minute Isha Kriya process in one session and practice on your own, or return to class to ask questions and deepen the experience with the group. Benefits of regular practice include improving health, energy and vitality; enhancing mental focus, memory and clarity; reducing stress and establishing a deep sense of peace and inner balance.

Isha Kriya is a gentle, seated practice, which can be practiced in a chair. No previous meditation experience is necessary.

The Isha Kriya process was developed by realized yogi, Sadhguru Vasudev. Sadhguru is renowned for his powerful yoga and meditation programs, as well as thriving humanitarian initiatives. He has been hosted to speak and offer meditations at numerous global leadership forums, businesses and universities, including the United Nations, the World Economic Forum, the British House of Lords, TED, MIT, and the World Peace Congress.

This free session will be facilitated by a trained Isha Kriya instructor. Contact: [masked],[masked] for more information about Isha USA or this session.

For more on Sadhguru and Isha, visit IshaUSA.org/blog

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
Tech Networks of Boston (also known as TNB) is pleased to invite local employees of nonprofit organizations to a Roundtable session
What nonprofits can (and cannot) learn from Wikipedia 
 with Joseph Reagle of Northeastern University.

Here’s what Joseph says about this session:

“Wikipedia’s success often prompts others to look to the online encyclopedia as a source of lessons on how to make good use of collaborative web technologies. I caution that we should be wary of the “wiki-pixie dust” myth that deploying a wiki will automatically foster the collaboration and success one sees at Wikipedia. I will frame our round-table discussion by identifying the technical and collaborative attributes of Wikipedia’s success with an appreciation of what is novel to its mission and historical circumstances. I’ll also briefly demonstrate how Wikipedia collaboration works and compare it to other platforms including Google Docs and Hackpad.”

In keeping with the spirit of the TNB Roundtable series, this session will not be a sales pitch for any product or service.  It will be a professional development opportunity for nonprofit professionals who want to learn with and from their peers in other organizations.

Please also note:

1) This session is for employees of nonprofit organizations. It is not designed to meet the needs of vendors, volunteers, students, consultants, job-seekers, and others.

Register here:  https://www.eventbrite.com/e/tnb-roundtable-what-nonprofits-can-and-cannot-learn-from-wikipedia-registration-17266900765

results.description:
$20 to attend. Please be on time and only sign up if you're sure you can be here.


Limited to four attendees. In this workshop, we'll read your work and take more time than in a standard group workshop to go into deeper detail regarding how to strengthen it. From larger structural and character considerations to minor formatting and story bumps, we'll go page by page and suggest how to make your script tighter, evocative, and more compelling. 


Please bring at least four copies of ONE of the following:

1. Ten pages of an original feature screenplay (or a ten or less-page short film) that you wrote yourself.
2. A treatment that you wrote yourself (one to two-page synopsis of the plot) for a proposed original screenplay. Please keep treatments to two pages maximum.


If you haven't written a script or treatment, then come with your questions and a willingness to provide constructive feedback for others.


Regardless of what you bring, be sure to PRINT OUT COPIES so that we can read it together. If you don't print them out, we'll have no way to workshop your work! At least four would be appreciated.

If you haven't written a screenplay or treatment but are curious about the process, then we definitely have a place for you. For beginners, we highly recommend grabbing a copy of The Complete Screenwriter's Manual (http://www.amazon.com/Complete-Screenwriters-Manual-Comprehensive-Reference/dp/0321397932) and screenwriting software (free: CeltX.com, more features: FinalDraft.com)

For more personalized script attention, I offer one-on-one screenplay coverage services. Details and testimonials: http://www.screenplay.guru. 10% off for Cambridge Screenwriting members.

We can't wait to see you!
results.name: Small Group Screenplay Workshop - $20

results.description:
Please note that this is a BYOD lab.

You will also need a Bluemix and DevOps account for the workshop.  Please follow these instructions prior to coming to the session.


1.  Register for Bluemix for free at:  www.ibm.biz/cloudboston

2.  Fill in the details to create an IBM ID (this ID  will be used to sign in to Bluemix and hub.jazz.net. 

3.  In a few minutes you will receive an email with a button to confirm your account.   Once you click the button you will be redirected to sign in to Bluemix.

4.  Go to https://hub.jazz.net and click on log in at the top right hand corner.

5.  Click on sign in and sign in with the ID you created for Bluemix.

6.  Create an alias. This will be used to authenticate when using git tools or cli and click finish.  You are now ready to start coding on the web. 

Agenda

-  Intro to Bluemix and IoT

-  Demo devices (Raspberry Pi, Arduino, Edison, TI Sensor tag)

-  Edison setup and connect to Bluemix

-  Lab exercise using Edison

-  Class to connect to sensor via API key and walk through Node-RED lab
results.name: Hands on Bluemix Workshop : IoT

results.description:
Level - Middle intermediates (currently playing volleyball regularly, understands and follows basic rules, able to execute basic pass, set and hit skills, and has good fitness).

Do you want to learn about or improve your sand doubles game?  Transition your indoor skills to the beach?  Improve consistency of your game in the sand?  Join us every Tue!  This is the 2nd season and it is still free!

5:45 to 6:30 – Review beach strategies and work through skill building drills

6:00-7:30 – Play beach/sand doubles on a men's height net 

If you have a good quality beach net, court ropes, or ball, please bring it!  More nets = more hits.

I am looking forward to sharing many of the skills and strategies I have learned from clinics I have taken.  FYI I am not a professional/certified coach and my level is as described above, generally know what to do but don't always execute consistently.

Reminder to bring water, sunglasses, bug spray and a beach chair. I will be wearing a gray November Project t shirt (same as profile pic).

ATTENDEES and RSVPs

The way the system works, you have to register for each week.  You can register about 3 weeks in advance.

We are trying to build a group of people who attend all (or most Wed nights).

The way the coaching is organized, it builds on previous weeks, so it is preferable to have the same/similar group each week. 

In order to encourage that, when confirming the RSVPs, I will give preference to participants who have attended previously.

Again, I am doing this to encourage a regular group of people.  I regret any frustration that this may cause if your RSVP status is changed.

DIRECTIONS

Carson Beach (limited free parking available), William Day Blvd, South Boston, http://www.bostonharborwalk.com...­

The net is blue. There are 2 parking lots (one on each side of beach house). Park in the southern lot (closer to State Police barracks) (or the one on the right side of the beach house as you look at the ocean). You will be able to see me and the net from there.

results.description:
**********************************

Agenda:

**********************************

Semantic Standards Enable Financial Data Synergy

David Blaszkowsky, SVP, Head of Data Governance, State Street


David Saul, SVP and Chief Scientist, State Street


ABSTRACT


Financial services companies want to develop new data analytics products and services for their clients. The increasing complexity and cost of global regulatory compliance diverts attention and resources from those efforts. The development of data standards, through industry partnerships like the Enterprise Data Management (EDM) Council, when combined with semantic technologies creates a synergy that can address both requirements. Development of the Legal Entity Identifier (LEI) from a regulatory mandate is one example of how public/private collaboration can work to the benefit of both. The Financial Industry Business Ontology (FIBO) is an emerging standard from the Object Management Group (OMG) that exploits semantics to describe data so that it can be used for both data analytics and risk management. Semantic data standards enhance data governance through their ability to create transparency both internally and externally.

ABOUT THE SPEAKERS

David M. Blaszkowsky joined State Street in 2014 from the Office of Financial Research, US Department of the Treasury, where he was Senior Policy Advisor, working on data and technology issues related to financial institution and systemic risk, including standards, data strategy, and emerging data technologies.  Prior to joining the OFR, the Securities and Exchange Commission appointed David in October 2007 as Director of its new Office of Interactive Disclosure, which developed and implemented interactive data rules, standards (particularly XBRL), and analytical tools for SEC financial disclosures. At both the SEC and OFR, David co-created and helped promote the adoption of the Legal Entity Identifier (LEI), as an original member of the “Linchpin” team.  Before his stints in government, David managed several equity research and analytics businesses for Standard & Poor's in New York. Before that, he was the director of strategic planning and development for McGraw-Hill's Construction Information Group, held finance and reengineering roles at Fidelity Investments, and was a management consultant at McKinsey & Company, Price Waterhouse (now PwC) and Gemini.  David received his B.A. in Economics at the University of Chicago, and his MBA in Finance at Northwestern University’s Kellogg School of Management.  David lives in Boston with his wife and two daughters.

David Saul is Senior Vice President and Chief Scientist at State Street Corporation, reporting to the Chief Information Officer.  In this role, he is responsible for proposing and assessing new advanced technologies for the organization as well as evaluating technologies already in use at State Street and their likely evolution in order to reinforce the organization’s leadership position in financial services.  Mr. Saul previously was Chief Information Security Officer, where he oversaw State Street’s corporate information security program, controls and technology.  Prior to that, he managed State Street’s Office of Architecture, where he was responsible for the overall enterprise technology, data and security architecture of the corporation.  Mr. Saul joined State Street in 1992 after 15 years with IBM’s Cambridge Scientific Center, where he managed innovations in operating systems virtualization, multiprocessing, networking and personal computers.  Mr. Saul serves as a Trustee of the Massachusetts Eye and Ear Infirmary.  In 2007 he was honored with a Computerworld Premier 100 IT Leader Award.  American Banker named Mr. Saul as one of its Top Innovators of 2013 for his work on data semantics and standards.  Mr. Saul holds Bachelors and Master’s degrees from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
results.how_to_find_us: Rm 32-D463, 4th floor, Star Conference Room, Stata Center, MIT
results.name: Cambridge Semantic Web Monthly Meetup: Semantic Standards Enable Financial Data

results.description:
The Science of Happier Spending

Does money buy happiness? Harvard Business School Professor Michael Norton shows that it sometimes can - when you follow five core principles of smarter spending. Michael is the co-author, with Elizabeth Dunn, of Happy Money: The Science of Happier Spending, and he's joining us on Tuesday July 14th for a special talk about his research and book. 

Their book provides five research-based principles designed to help people use their money in happier ways - whether they have a little or a lot of it. The book is full of recent research and examples that range from how individuals gain happiness by choosing "experiences over stuff" to how companies seek to create happier employees and 'happier products' for their customers. 

Here's the schedule: 

6:00 - 6:30 Free food & drink while networking

6:30 - 7:30 Talk and discussion


See you all there!


About Michael:

Michael I. Norton is a Professor at the Harvard Business School. He is the co-author – with Elizabeth Dunn – of the book, Happy Money: The Science of Happier Spending. In 2012, he was selected for Wired Magazine’s Smart List as one of “50 People Who Will Change the World” and his TEDx talk, How  to Buy Happiness, has been viewed more than 2.8 million times.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PsihkFWDt3Y

TRANSPORTATION: Red line/Commuter Rail to South Station, or Orange Line to Chinatown or Downtown Crossing stops. Parking: On-street meter parking available (2 hour meters until 8pm), or public parking garages in the area.  In particular, the garage at the Hyatt is somewhat reasonably priced and just a couple blocks walking distance.
results.name: The Science of Happier Spending

Data Visualization with Plotly & Programmatic Back-ends


-Abstract:


This meetup will focus on exciting new web technologies for graphing and data analysis while discussing data visualization best practices.  Further, the talk with elaborate on how Plotly remade historically important maps with a  modern twist.  Those participating in the demonstration will learn how to can make interactive versions of graphs  (and many more) with Plotly, D3.js, Python, R and other programs. 


Finally, the attendees will also learn about the functions in Plotly  and how it can leverage for work and business. 

-Speaker Biography:

Marianne Corvellec speaks and teaches regularly at science/techevents. She is a certified instructor with Software Carpentry. Since
2013, she has been an instructor and helper at many workshops about
Python programming and data analysis (including but not limited to
Software Carpentry workshops). She spoke at SciPy 2013, useR! 2014,
and co-instructed a tutorial at PyCon 2015. Marianne did a PhD in
statistical physics (Ecole Normale Supérieure de Lyon, France,
2008–2012) from which she gained expertise in statistics and
scientific plotting. Also, she TAed many tutorials and labs at the
undergraduate level. Marianne thus has experience teaching a variety
of audiences: non-programmers, novices, women groups, undergraduate
and graduate students, scientists.
results.name: Data Visualization with Plotly & Programmatic Back-ends

results.description:
Our society is no longer moving as we once did. Opportunities for natural movement have diminished from long days of static sitting at work or school! It is affecting our attention, health and emotions. Learn how one community of makers put movement back into daily lives, using engaging items...a musical hopscotch, a jumping wall wired with a Makey Makey, a cardboard rocker and a pedaling machine that lights and plays music. Make something with us and experience how fun it is to move again! "Over the weekend of August 8 and 9 the cities of Boston, Cambridge and Somerville will come alive with a public Fab Festival. The 3-city Festival is a celebration of making and creativity. The weekend includes exhibitions, demonstrations, cool performances, hands-on activities for the whole family, and talks and panels featuring great makers from around the world. The Fab Festival is free and open to the public. Check the Fab Festival program often as new, fun activities will be added daily by Fabbers from across the city and around the globe!" -- www.fab11.org


HATCH will be participating in FABFest, we are going to make a community project called "Make to Move" to present during our workshop. We are going to build an electric device that will help people get interested in exercise. We will be discussing ideas and taking suggestions during our first meeting.


If you are interested in working on this project or just want to learn more about what we are doing we will be meeting every Tuesday from July 7th through the 28th 6-8pm. Hope to see you there.
results.how_to_find_us: HATCH is located at the Arsenal Mall/Project at 485 Arsenal St. Park by the entrance that has a big green HATCH sign over the doors. You'll find us between Pearle Vision and Game Stop.
results.name: FabFEST project: Make to Move

results.description:
Big Data Analytics with Apache Solr 

Solr has been the de facto full-text search engine for the Hadoop stack, but developers are increasingly using it for real-time analytics. This talk will cover recent advancements in Solr's faceted search, statistics, and analytics as well as how those capabilities are being integrated with other search functionality such as grouping and joins.

Yonik Seeley is a Software Engineer at Cloudera and is the creator of Apache Solr. Yonik was previously the chief open source architect and co-founder at Lucid Imagination, a company dedicated to development and support of Lucene/Solr. He’s also an Apache Lucene/Solr PMC member and committer.

Spend some time on your project by bringing it along to our weekly project night, an evening designed around you and what you're working on.

This weekly event is about finding time to tinker, being creative, and meeting other members of the community.  You'll get the chance to see what others are working on, share your projects, and to get inspiration and feedback from fellow tinkerers.

On any given Tuesday night you have people working on electronics, knitting, writing code, wood-working, or just their plans for world domination. Beer is also consumed.

We’ll provide: space to work, basic tools, power, a room full of like minded people.

You’ll provide: your project, ideas and beer. A laptop would probably be useful too.

Sometimes we work on group projects together, which are usually set up as separate meetup events. Keep an eye on our events page to see what we’re working on next.

Cloud Technology Partners HQ

263 Summer Street, 4th Floor


Boston, MA 02210 


Thank you to Cloud Technology Partners for sponsoring food & drink and a presentation.


This is an RSVP event. Please come prepared to identify with your Meetup account. Thank you to the Amazon team, and specifically Ricardo DeMatos, who has helped make these arrangements - venue, and end presentation!

Agenda:
6:30-7:00 Food and networking
7:00-9L00 (presentations) 


Presentations:

Overview of AWS certification. An overview of the market demand for Cloud computing professionals, their roles in Cloud architecture, and the different options for training and certification, including online labs available.


Presenter: Raphael Soeiro, Sr. Technical Trainer/Evangelist with AWS Training & Certification, has 15 years of IT experience (14 with EMC Corp), with strong infrastructure service background. Raphael holds several industry certifications along with years of hands-on experience. He teaches customers, employees and partners about AWS services and products. 

----------------


Practical Enterprise Application Migration to AWS: How Much Should You Change? We’ll explore recent case studies of enterprise legacy application migration to AWS, including how we addressed clients' key concerns, the options we considered and the recommendations we made.

Presenter: Kacy Clarke, Vice President, Principal Architect at Cloud Technology Partners, and AWS Certified Solutions Architect. Kacy has 30+ years of experience in both traditional and cloud architectures. She has spent the last 4 years at CTP working with large enterprises on cloud strategy, cloud application migration, multi-cloud operations and distributed, large-scale data management.


----------------

results.description:
City Growers/ Urban Farming Institute 

Image adapted from original by Boston Red Sox


Let's talk about growing food in the city! 


We're convinced that the most positive impact we can have in improving the way the world eats is by inspiring individuals to source and eat locally grown food, or to grow their own food in their indoor or outdoor gardens. We're so excited to learn more about the local farmers making that possible in our city!

Join us at Greentown Labs in Somerville for drinks, snacks and discussion around Boston's great urban ag projects.

6:30PM - 7:00PM Hang out and enjoy refreshments!
7:00 - 7:15PM Intro by Jamie Byron
7:15 - 7:30PM City Growers/ Urban Farming Institute   
7:30 - 8:00PM Jessie Banhazl from Green City Growers
8:00 - 8:30PM Drinks, discussion 

Jessie at Green City Growers (creators of Fenway Farms)

Jessie has managed Green City Growers since inception in 2008 to profitability while establishing GCG as the leader in urban agriculture in the Northeast. Jessie was named “…arguably the queen of Boston’s urban ag visionaries” by Stuff Magazine, among the Top 40 Under 40 by Boston Business Journal, Top 30 Under 30 by Zagat, and a Root Cause 2013 Social Innovator. In 2015, Green City Growers and the Boston Red Sox launched a 5,000 square foot rooftop farm on top of Fenway Park that provides fresh, organic fruit and vegetables to Red Sox fans. 

City Growers/ Urban Farming Institute 

City Growers works with community partners to secure land in the city for growing food. Imagine the positive impact of converting abandoned city lots into thriving green farms -- that's how City Growers is contributing to the new green economy in communities where economic revitalization is needed most. In the coming years, they'll create a checkerboard of productive green space in Boston’s inner city where local growing talent thrives.


With an introduction by Jamie Byron at Grove Labs! 

Grove Labs is a Somerville startup empowering everyone to grow their own food one aquaponic system at a time. Our first product, the Grove Ecosystem, is a residential aquaponic system designed to fit seamlessly into your kitchen. It's connected to a mobile app that guides you along the way and connects you to other users in the community. We aim to make aquaponic indoor growing a more approachable, viable and efficient way to produce your own fresh, organic food at home.

------

A note about our venue, Greentown Labs: 

We enable entrepreneurs to solve big energy problems. We face a growing global population and the resources required to meet expanding demand is today's most pressing challenge. New ways of producing and consuming energy are necessary to address this problem while minimizing further damage to our environment. We believe entrepreneurs are capable of innovating and inventing solutions to address this challenge with access to the right tools, resources, network and support -- that's where we come in.
results.name: Food in the City: Meet Fenway Farms

results.description:
19th Annual Make-a-Mark Tuesday, July 14, 2015

Note: This event is open to the general public 21+ event. You must take further action to buy a ticket. Your rsvp here on meetup site does not guarantee admission.

Weather Check http://www.timeanddate.com/weather/usa/boston


At the door $85

About Make-A-Mark

The Courageous community came together on Pier 4 for the 18th annual Make-a-Mark, our signature summertime gala and fundraiser for Courageous's youth development programs. We're so happy to report that it could hardly have gone better, with complimentary hors d'oeuvres, beer, wine, and cocktails plus music from the Baha Brothers, and two auctions -- a perfect night out for nearly 600 Courageous friends and supporters who came out to Charlestown.

Through the generosity of all of our sponsors and guests, we raised over $100,000! Every dollar goes directly to support Courageous kids, helping them not only to learn how to sail, but also to succeed in life. As you know, Courageous Sailing exists to serve Boston kids - 1100 this year, our biggest group ever. And Courageous continues to exist because of all our supporters. With your help, Courageous kids are building self-confidence, life skills, and job skills - and most would never have this kind of opportunity without Courageous.

We're already looking forward to Make-a-Mark 2015 -- hope to see you there! Until then, catch up withphotos from the 2014 event on Facebook.

Complimentary Beer, Wine, Cocktails, Hors d'Oeuvres, & Live Music

Local businesses pitched in to make the 2014 event even more memorable. Complimentary beer, wine, and and cocktails provided by Dirty Water Distillery, Gosling's Dark n Stormy, Samuel Adams, Gordon's Wines and Premier Bartending paired well with delicious hors d'oeuvres from The Fireplace, Capers Catering, Pier 6 and Captain Mardens. Under the Peterson Party Center tent, the Baha Brothers kept things lively all night long.

results.description:
Gentlepeople,

We're meeting on Tuesday 7/14 NEW LOCATION in Wellesley.  Details follow.

In Tuesday, on July14th, your Boston Network Users Group, BNUG, will meet at Mass Bay Community College in Wellesley Hills to learn about balancing and comparing local versus cloud computing.  As usual, admission is FREE and open to all.  Munchies and Intermingling (M&I) starts at 6:30pm, the meeting will start at 7pm and must end by 8:30pm. 

IMPORTANT: You need to have a (free) parking pass and directions.  You can download this from http://www.bnug.org/parkingpermit

About the meeting: 

Keep your feet in the mud but look at the stars: Finding the balance between local and cloud computing

For the last ten years, vast resources have been used to make web-based systems to replace local systems.  This movement has had many advantages and disadvantages.  A good way to see them is to make some specific comparisons.  We’ll make them, and, as we do, always keep these issues in mind:

Big issues:

• The web makes sharing easier. 

•  For effective web work, you have to have high speed connectivity and the latest browser.

• Getting locked out of your web account.

• Can you fulfill your responsibility to protect data?

• Web interfaces can change at whim—and not necessarily YOUR whim

• Shifting privacy and other policies-- e.g. Google reading your mail to advertise, the enormous influence of secret search policies

• Golden rule-- he who has the gold makes  the rules. 

• How does this condition online services?

• Rent vs own

Here are some of the specific comparisons we’ll discuss: 

• Backups:  Acronis vs. Carbonite (The pros and cons of these two approaches, and how they can complement each other.) 

• Remote access: Logmein vs. Radmin 

• Google docs vs. Word/Excel 

• Gmail vs. Outlook for Windows 

• Databases: filemaker vs. salesforce 

• Web design itself: dreamweaver vs. wordpress 

• ODB vs. Google contacts  

• Quickbooks vs. Quickbooks online

About the speaker Adam Frost

Adam Frost works as the coordinator of Computer Care and Learning, an educationally-oriented computer helping company. While some of our colleagues and competitors encourage “outsourcing” of all computer care to them, we encourage our customers to get to know their computers and train their staff in computer care. We find this helps our customers develop deep skills in computer use as a key part of business strategy and action.

Computer Care and Learning has a longstanding internship program, where we train people to be skilled computer helpers, and we also help run the Get Connected! clinic, which provides refurbished computers to customers with low and moderate incomes.

To learn more, come to the meeting, call us at[masked], or email [masked]

FINALLY, thanks for reading this far.  I'm always open to your comments and suggestions, and even your questions and clever jokes (especially the latter).

Regards,
-steve
Steve Isenberg
President, BNUG

results.name: Balancing Local and Cloud Computing

results.description:
Contact me [Jose (click the link, then click "Message")] for the address.

General board gaming. We have a good library of widely played board games, and people normally bring many more of them. We regularly run three to five tables of board games - this provides enough variety.  It is normal for people to get two or three games a session.  The game night format was inspired by Unity Games and the event is very casual and structureless.  If you have gone to one of the meetup's quarterly events you will know.

Q & A:

Q.  What types of games are played?
A.  Any type of board game.  Browse through the most popular games at http://boardgamegeek.com/ and that should give you an idea.

Q.  Until when do you play games?  Can I arrive later than 7pm?
A.  Until the last game of the evening ends, usually past midnight.  Yes, you can arrive later than 7pm, but you may have to wait for a new game to start if you do.

Q.  Should I bring something?  
A.  If you want, bring a game you feel comfortable teaching. There will be pizza and sodas served. Feel free to bring snacks or beverages to share or chip in $5 to $10 for the pizza/sodas in the pizza cup. 

Q.  I really want to play XYZ game, can we schedule it?
A.  Some people ask for interest in a particular game on the event comments below.  This may be the way to make sure you get to play the game you want. 

Q.  Where do I park?
A.  The driveway is the obvious spot, but eventually it will fill up on most of these game nights.  Some people do park on the street.  The soccer field parking across the street is a safe option and is the suggestion the town police gave me when I asked about overflow parking.
results.how_to_find_us: The house is just across from a soccer field.  If the driveway starts to fill up, the soccer field parking lot is a good option.

This Meetup is intended for intermediate level players or higher, which means:Yankee C and above level, players with firm understanding of game strategy. Should be able to play 5-1 and 6-2 formations, have a good grasp of skills (passing, setting, hitting) and be able to move around to cover areas of the court. Play should consistently be bump-set-spike.



If you'd like to play, please do the following:


1. Send an email to Kory using the following URL: http://www.meetup.com/volleyball-122/message/?recipientId=8675200

2. In the message please indicate the date of event and your preferred position so we can make sure we have the right mix. ( If I don't know your position already)

Note that sending an email does not guarantee a spot to play; spots are only guaranteed if you receive a positive confirmation email. We will do our best to make sure the event is co-ed, have setters,  and incorporate a couple new members who want to join as well.

The location for this volleyball meetup is at the Orient Heights Community Center located at 86 Boardman Street in East Boston. Kory and Wing will be hosting these Tuesday night volleyball meetups.

This event is free if you are a member of Boston Community Centers. If not, it's a one-time $20 membership fee that is valid for a year. The Community Center is a short walk away from the Orient Heights T Stop on the Blue Line and also has plenty of parking. When you drive up, turn at the Mariott Hotel Sign and park in the lot or further along the fence.

As always, please remember:

- Respect the RSVP system (Don't show up expecting to play without a confirmed RSVP)

- The gym is open before the event to warm up, so please arrive a little early if you would like to warm up and stretch as we would like to start the game promptly from 7:00PM

- If it looks like you won't be able to make it or will run late please cancel your RSVP in time for someone else to join.  Event day/last minute cancellations and no shows will jeopardize your participation in future events.
